Seeing all those white coats in one room just waiting to talk to us personally was unnerving to say the least. The amazingly detailed staff explained to us that the MRI had shown that this mass was a urinoma, but that they didn’t fully know what the fluid was exactly yet. They informed us that the baby needs amniotic fluid around it (which our baby had close to none) for healthy lung development prior to birth. Without this development, life simply is not possible. They also informed us that there was a bladder obstruction which is what actually caused the urinoma. Doctors explained that the kidneys at the time they were functioning, got backed up because of the pressure of not being able to be released through the bladder. The blockage and backup is ultimately what caused damage to Israel’s kidneys. The staff informed us that we had the option to do nothing, which they are obligated to say. The doctors explained that doing nothing would mean almost certain death for Israel. A second option was given, to proceed with steps to counter these problems and come up with a plan. They informed us that if we decided to move forward with this, that this would more than likely be a very hard, long road to travel. I promptly made it clear to them all that this is a child, not just any child - it’s our child. This is a human being and we are going to fight as hard as we possibly can for this little one, no matter what strains or hardships are in store for our future. The doctors looked to each other as if to all be in understanding around the room that our decision was clear. After a brief pause, one of the doctors spoke up and said that if we were planning on moving forward, the first step would be to do a procedure that involves sticking a needle into Monica’s lower abdomen to extract the fluid from the urinoma. He further explained that the procedure would involve either pulling the needle out just far enough to infuse artificial amniotic fluid, or potentially utilizing an additional needle for the amino fusion. I asked him when he could perform this thinking to myself we would have to wait another week or so, but he promptly said “I can do this for you tomorrow”. My wife and mother immediately teared up and we all sincerely and genuinely thanked the specialists numerous times before leaving the room, my wife and mother hugging most of them as we left.Early Thursday morning, around 2:30am, I woke up, not able to sleep and opened up the Bible app on my phone. The first verse that came up was Genesis 32:22, where Jacob wrestled with God, and God renames him Israel. Since we found out we were pregnant while in Jerusalem, we had already considered naming our baby Israel, but after reading this passage on that nervous, early Thursday morning, I felt like I was wrestling with God through the current situation and like this baby was wrestling for his life. After discussing my thoughts further with Monica that morning we decided our baby’s name will be Israel. That morning my wife and I met my mother at the hospital and went in for the procedure. I remember being nervous, especially for my wife, but we knew we were in very good, very capable hands. The doctor explained to us that with this procedure, there is a low risk of premature birth or miscarriage, but a risk just the same, so Monica signed the waiver and he started. Seeing a doctor insert an 8 inch needle into your wife is unpleasant, and I can only imagine the physical feeling that it gave her was even more so, but I held her hand as he started the procedure, all the while, keeping my eyes glued to the sonogram monitor. The doctor ended up draining 120mls from the urinoma, which is about a half cup of fluid from this little baby’s stomach. I remember seeing how much fluid he extracted and just wondering to myself “how?” I then saw from the sonogram monitor the doctor pull the needle out just enough to position the tube where it needed to go in order to infuse the artificial amniotic fluid, and started to infuse. I honestly can’t tell you the feeling that swept over me as I saw this amazing doctor breath hope and life back into our child, even now writing this, it brings tears to my eyes. We could physically see this fluid rush in on the monitor, and our little creation of God immediately respond by moving his arms and legs, feeling the fluid that started to surround him, playing in it... It is a sight that I will never forget as long as I live.After the procedure, the doctor informed us that they would send off the fluid for testing and would have the results back in a couple weeks. He told us that we would have to return to Cincinnati weekly for these extractions and infusions, for the next month or two and that towards the end of the pregnancy, we would have to return twice a week ultimately having to relocate to Cincinnati for the rest of her pregnancy and possibly some time afterwards. We went back to the hotel so that Monica could rest before we had to travel the four and a half hours back home the next morning. I immediately started to think about the severity of how our lives were going to change and what we could do in order to adapt the very best way possible.Since then, we have gone back to Cincinnati every week. On the third visit they received the results of the fluid from the urinoma and told us that they are abnormal, meaning that the kidneys aren’t functioning properly and Israel will more than likely need to be put on peritoneal dialysis after he is born. This also means that we will have to stay in Cincinnati for an average of six months and that baby Israel will have to be hooked up to a dialysis machine for a few years until he is eligible for a kidney transplant. Monica and I will also have to take training classes in order to understand how to do everything properly once we are able to bring him back home with us. The doctors don’t know how the lungs will develop and as of right now, they are right below the low end of normal, so there is still hope on that front.Needless to say, this is a very stressful and overwhelming time for everyone involved, but there is no other option. I can’t not love my unborn son and refuse to do anything less than fight as hard as I can for him. Throughout this entire endeavor thus far, the one constant is Israel’s strong, beating heart, it is unwavering as is ours to do everything we can to love this child. We humbly ask that you keep us in your hearts and in your prayers, and that you share our story with everyone that you know. We will continue to have faith that ultimately, this little baby’s life is in God’s hands. We have been fortunate enough to have amazing support from friends and family and will without a doubt keep everyone that donates, prays, and who has helped in any way completely informed and updated. Thank you so much for taking the time to learn about our story, God bless you all.

title: 9 fingers, 9 lives - Jeff’s Journey
text: As most of you know by now, Jeff Short, his wife Sarah and four-year-old daughter Emma need our support.On Tuesday, August 14, Jeff was traveling south on Interstate 81 in Virginia when he was involved in a devastating accident. Even then, God placed a guardian angel with Jeff when a relative happened to be only a few cars behind. Once he identified Jeff, he used a crow bar to gain entry and pull him from his vehicle. Jeff was then med-flighted to Roanoke Memorial Hospital.￼￼Upon his admission, it was discovered Jeff had no feeling below his chest line. He had suffered what doctors called a catastrophic injury to his spinal cord as well as other acute injuries.Jeff’s medical team was able to stabilize his condition, but after further evaluation doctor’s suggested a surgery to stabilize and decompress Jeff’s spine. Roughly 24 hours after his initial arrival Jeff’s surgical team performed a procedure to insert a series of rods and screws into his spine. What doctors found during Jeff’s surgery was a complete spinal cord injury at his T2 vertebrae. His spinal cord was extremely inflamed and his dura shredded.While Jeff’s surgery was successful, he still remains in the ICU on blood pressure stabilization meidications and doctors were clear that it was unlikely that Jeff would ever walk again. As Jeff shifts modes to recovery we must pray that he is the one in a million that can beat the odds. However, as we pray and support Jeff in his journey, the interim is sure to be full of challenges.There will be many expenses associated with Jeff’s journey to recovery: hotels, meals, babysitters, dog sitters, travel, the list is longer than any of us can fathom.A dime, a dollar, a dozen - anything you can give to remove financial burden through these trying times is going to aide in Jeff’s recovery. And more important than pennies are prayers. Find time to pray as often as possible for Jeff, Sarah, Emma and their family.Thank you for being a part of Jeff’s Journey. And remember, “Our prayers may be awkward. Our attempts may be feeble. But since the power of prayer is in the one who hears it and not in the one who says it, our prayers do make a difference.”

title: Support the Regans
text: Imagine hearing the words, “Your son has cancer”. You cry, you fight, and you do whatever it takes to get your child healthy again. You win the battle, and think your journey with cancer is finally behind you. Then, 10 years later, you hear those same words about your younger son. This is the reality that my best friends, Dawn and Pete Regan are living. Their son Jack is a Leukemia survivor. Their son Quinn was just diagnosed with Ewing’s Sarcoma.For those that know them, the Regans are positive, fun-loving, and would do absolutely anything for their family and friends. It’s time to come together and show them that we are with them every step of the way as Quinn starts his battle. Please, click below and donate what you can. Then, forward this to everyone you know and ask them to do the same. Let’s at least try to ease the financial burden for this amazing family, while they focus on getting Quinn healthy.

title: Jeremy's Battle Against ALS
text: Barrington Hills Police Department (BHPD) Officer Jeremy Hensler was recently diagnosed with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), also commonly referred to as Lou Gehrig's disease, which is progressively debilitating and eventually terminal. As we all know, lives, priorities, and future plans can change in an instant and this is sadly the case for Officer Hensler. Jeremy is a 13-year veteran of BHPD and served five years as a police officer in Richardson, Texas before moving to Illinois with his wife and young daughter. His daughter is now 15 years old, beginning her high school years and is the light of Jeremy's life.Jeremy has spent all of his adult life in public service and he has gone above and beyond in his career at BHPD, serving 12 years as a Northern Illinois Police Alarm System (NIPAS) Emergency Services Team (EST) sniper. Jeremy is also a 10-year veteran of the United States Marine Corps in which he served as an infantry rifleman in the 1st Battalion 9th Regiment at Camp Pendleton, California – consequently, he is very proud and was initially reluctant in allowing Department members to organize a request for assistance on his behalf.Jeremy is currently on an administrative desk assignment and is in the process of obtaining a non-duty-related disability. He will need progressively more care and assistance during the course of this terrible disease. While we all pray for a miracle cure or remission, we also realistically know that the financial strain on Jeremy is something he should not need to worry about. Any assistance you may provide to assist Jeremy in facing this difficult disease will be greatly appreciated by him, his daughter, and the entire Barrington Hills Police Department staff.  Thank you,Barrington Hills PD

title: Ryan's Treatment Related Expenses
text: The repeated requests to setup this page to help with my treatment related expenses have been heart warming to say the least.  My family and I can't thank you enough for your enthusiasm and desire to help! Donations will go toward supporting treatment related expenses (travel, lodging, etc), the Graft Versus Host Disease center at MD Anderson and a medical housing non-profit to help patients better afford their cost of living. For those that would like to learn more about Graft Versus Host Disease (GVHD), please take a moment to visit this wikipedia link below:Graft Versus Host Disease (Wikipedia) Thank you!Ryan and family

title: Fitz - Friends and Family
text: As you may know, our Michael "Fitz" is facing a health challenge and will undergo simultaneous chemotherapy and radiation for seven weeks. While his prognosis and attitude are very good, a series of untimely events have left the family with costly insurance payments through Cobra and a single income through Michael's chiropractic business. It is anticipated that the treatment will be debilitating to a certain extent and at some point, Michael may not be able to work.Throughout the years Michael has been such a great source of support, generosity and love to all. Many of you have asked how you can help.It's simple - in his time of need, please contribute to this campaign today. Heartfelt Thanks!

title: Play for Gavin
text: Our 15 year old son Gavin is in the fight of his life battling MRSA. He has already shown victory over a brain tumor when he was 10 and now in time he will shine victory over this. Family and water polo are Gavin's life.This is extremely hard for our family to do...we are not one's to ask for assistance but we are currently feeling as if we are out of options. Our son is very sick, vacation time off is dwindling and medical bills are expected to be substantial.

title: Stockhaus Fund
text: In December 2017 after experiencing ongoing stomach pain, a colonoscopy revealed that Jaimeson had colon cancer.  Weeks later they removed a portion of his colon along with his appendix and then began chemotherapy. After 3 months of chemo treatments they did a mid-treatment scan and discovered that the cancer was back and appeared to have spread in his abdominal wall (peritoneum) and was not responding to the chemo. There is a long road ahead as they re-access treatment & surgical options. With 4 young children the Stockhaus' are in great need of full time help with their children along with other day to day needs to allow them to focus on Jaimeson's health & treatments. Please consider donating towards this fund which will help with their very real and tangible needs. Every little amount helps and they are so so grateful for your help in their time of need.Thank you for supporting this sweet family!Jaimeson (44), Christi (37), Carter (7.5yrs), Jackson (5.5yrs), Savannah (1.5yrs) & James (1.5yrs)*there is zero platform fee, just a payment processing fee of 2.9% +$0.30 per donation. If you choose to leave a "tip" for the platform you may.Other ways to support the Stockhaus Family:Provide a Meal:  https://mealtrain.com/vqy73gUpdates:  https://www.caringbridge.org/visit/jaimesonstockhausInstacart Gift Cards:  https://www.instacart.com/help/section/200758544#115005645586*Please contact any of the following care coordinators if you have other ideas and ways you would like to support the Stockhaus' during this time- Ashley Boone ash268@gmail.com 214-212-5821- Mary Costello Mary.f.costello@gmail.com 669-273-6886- Courtney Dudley courtneydudley@gmail.com 713-992-6677- Teresa Ridenhour tmridenhour14@gmail.com 512-771-5992- Laurie Kushin lkushin@gmail.com 703-598-0941- Michelle Marx dancin.meesh@gmail.com 804-387-4470- Rachel McDaniel rdkraines@yahoo.com 480-292-5492- Annemarie Bollmanannemarie@thebollmans.com 805-618-0363- Betsy Coffin betsycoffin@gmail.com 805-729-2432- Holly Eldered hollyeldred@gmail.com 805-886-2480- Liz Medlin lizmedlin@gmail.com 857-488-5690

title: Join Fight to fight Cancer
text: Hi there!!!I am sharing this because I thought together we all would make a lot difference to help out our dear friend -  Anup, 34, is a husband, father, friend and co-worker, those of us that are fortunate to know Anup. He enjoys being around others and making them laugh and will always spread the positivity.He married in with his long time girlfriend Indira Sharma back in 2015 but as we all know, life isn't fair at times! In 2016 whilst he was enjoying his married life and was joyful to know about baby news, some other plans were also made for him. He was experiencing the blood in his coughing. It went on couple of days and then he made an appointment with doctor for check up. Test test test and test went on to figure it out that he has Lung Cancer of  Stage 4. Before starting up his treatments Anup had rigorous search on every doctors ,treatments and FAMILY expansion. I am sure he must have followed or learned to go with flow. When he must be staring at his new born baby, he must have counted every moment to make it day -by-day.I don't have ability to understand  a person with such great attitude with very lovely and kind heart has to breath "Sufferings"Well immediately treatments were started and he was getting treated with ' Immunotherapy'. He  wanted to opt for Sloan hospital for new treatments but never got a chance there. Then he started getting treatment with chemotherapy and Radiation.He was ok until he went through some surgeries last year but now his condition is worsened and now he is hospitalized 3 days back.Anup and his wife Indira has a big fight ahead and they need to be focused on this fight and not worry about the financial side of life. Sometimes people aren't sure how to help in times like this, but here is the answer: contribute any amount ASAP no matter how small to help Anup and his family stay focused.

title: Haley’s Fight Hope4Cancer Fund
text: Haley Miller-Wilhour was diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia on July 31, 2015, at only 27 years of age. In and out of the hospital the past three years, she has undergone 2 stem cell transplants, the most recent earlier this year. Unfortunately, Haley has received the devastating news that her cancer has returned again. With other options exhausted, Haley and her husband Justin along with their four young children are heading to Hope4Cancer, an integrative cancer treatment center in Tijuana, Mexico on Thursday, June 28th.  The initial cost once they arrive will be $45,000. This includes treatment only, no travel, food or lodging expenses for the family of six. We are asking all who see this to please consider donating. There is no amount too small or large. We serve a mighty God and we know He is with us in this fight. Thank you all.

title: Stem Cell Therapy for JV
text: This fund is to save a life. Born with Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC), a rare and "incurable" liver disease, this special person felt compelled to enter an important service career and found out during a physical for that career that he had PSC. He was unable to pass the physical and began using intense holistic medicine. That cleaned him up short term and allowed him to become established in his career, but soon manifested into debilitating Ulcerative Colitis. He then lost extreme weight, was bleeding consistently, ended up in the hospital multiple times and almost lost his life. He tried several modern medicine regiments for years, including a chemotherapy but the drugs did not help and in some cases deteriorated his body and liver even more. With discipline and diligence he was able to alter his diet and follow an intense holistic regimen and just limp along in his job and life. The “cure” for PSC is a liver transplant, but the medical community will not even consider putting him on the transplant list due to the Ulcerative Colitis, so there is no cure in current medical protocols. This is a young man with a wife and small child! Not willing to accept a death sentence he did infinite research and found a clinic out of the country that has a very high success rate with actually healing and correcting his diseases with stem cell infusion therapy. Your donation to this fund saves a life, and for those that know him, an incredibly important life dedicated to helping us all.My son is the beneficiary for this campaign  He will be withdrawing the funds to pay for his upcoming medical treatments.  His first treatment is scheduled in early August at which time he must have $27K to cover the first round of expenses. A secondary same cost treatment is anticipated later and God willing, a third or fourth treatment will not be needed.Again, thank you from the bottom of our hearts for the outpouring of love, kindness and support.

title: Pray for Rye Guy
text: On Saturday, April 21st, at 10:11 am Rick found Rye unresponsive.  Jazzy heroically dialed 911 while Rick and a neighbor (who is an ER doctor) began CPR.  Julie was at a Foreign Language Teachers Conference in Jenks.  Once both parents had arrived, the ER doctor kindly, but clearly explained that since there had been no oxygen to Rye's brain for approximately 30-40 minutes we would be having conversations about organ donation withing 24 hours and that he would not survive.  That has been the consistent message from medical teams from the beginning.  The brain was expected to reach peak swelling by around 72 hours.  If herniation did not occur before that, an MRI would be performed.  The MRI Wednesday afternoon confirmed that there was extreme damage and cell death at all levels of the brain and on both sides.  The very minimal activity was from a very abnormal brain sending very abnormal signs.  With that news, coupled with the absolute lack of any physical responsiveness to hourly neurological tests (light shining in eyes, pinching of fingers, swabbing of eyeballs, tickling of feet, etc.), the family was made aware that it would be acceptable at any point to proceed with donor matching.  The desire of our family the entire time is for God to either completely heal and save Rye's life or save the lives of others through organ donation.  We love that physical picture of how Christ lost his life to give others eternal life.  Doctors and amazing nurses have worked tirelessly to ensure via the respirator, all kinds of medicines and monitors that Rye's organs stay healthy.  Since Julie needed a bit of time to process things, she asked if Saturday, a week after the accident, would be a reasonable day to let go of this precious child who may very well have been in Heaven (not the hospital) the entire week and move forward with donation.  Doctors said that would be fine while offering another day to Rick, "we can do this earlier if you like."  While dreading that possible moment on Saturday, we prayed for God to give us any clear sign that Rye might possibly be in that body or that He make him completely brain dead so we could have no doubt in our minds that it is God, not us, taking our child's life.  Being a donor family comes with the complication that finality of earthly life is less visibly clear.  Even after declaration of death, machines will keep this child's body "alive."  We, as parents, will potentially not see our child breathe his last and have the closure of such a scene.  We may have already seen that.  Julie has repeatedly said that "I am not sure if Rye is in this hospital, but I am very sure that Jesus is. God is clearly in every person who visits, hugs, prays, brings coffee, sings over Rye, etc."         Friday, April 27, God blessed us with postponing our Saturday plans.  Rye showed an appropriate response to pain.  He moved his shoulder when his shoulder was pinched hard intentionally by the physician (instead of inappropriately moving his leg, for example).  His eyes opened.  We count those moments as God's kindness in letting us see his eyes again and in giving doctors a reason to wait things out a bit.  Again, doctors are very honest about how small a sign that is scientifically.      So, we wait.  And we pray.  And we rejoice that we have this time with Rye's physical body here so that the beautiful body of believers can join us in the grieving, hoping, waiting, praying, crying, singing, laughing, eating, hugging, holding, touching walking, talking, etc.  We thank our Father that, Rye, who has no living grandparents and no relatives in the state has the biggest family ever imagined in the brothers and sisters in Christ who internationally are going before the throne of the Creator of the Universe daily on his behalf.  We know God can heal him here completely.  We pray He will.  Regardless, we trust His character that never changes and is always good, always for us, always faithful, always loving and always righteous.

title: Naveed Minoofar
text: Naveed, 22 years of age , a student at CSUN, and a good hearted, smart, young man with lots of good faith. Naveed needs a lot of medical attention and has a long road to recovery. Naveed went into cardiac arrest on January 23 due to a severe flu virus. Most of his organs are damaged and he still requires a lot of attention. He fights every day to surmount this difficult road. Your donations help more than you think, however if you cannot donate, please share this post.vahid and Afsaneh Minoofar ask everyone to please pray for Naveed for a fast recovery. Thank you all and may God bless you and your families.Afsaneh Minoofar,  the mother of Naveed Minoofarwants to thank everyone for  their contributions and ask to keep Naveed in your prayers.

title: 6 Months My Ass!
text: Excuse my language, but that’s just how I’m feeling. It’s not everyday that you find out you have cancer. My name is Michelle Jannette Barroso, born and raised in San Francisco California and I just turned 48 years old this past June. I graduated from Immaculate Conception Academy, and then from Dominican College of San Rafael with my BSN. I am a registered nurse in Labor and Delivery at El Camino Hospital in Mountain View. I’m the wife of Eduardo Barroso who is a carpenter and works for the city of San Francisco for MUNI, and the proud mother of three beautiful children; Melissa and Loreto who are both in college, and Cheree who is in high school. On June 16th I was alarmed to find 11 pea sized lumps around my neck. So that following Wednesday I scheduled a doctors appointment, just to be safe and say I had it checked out. The following week on Junes 26th, we received the results of my biopsy. They told me they had found Adenocarcinoma, I had Cancer. We conducted the necessary diagnostic tests to find out how severe my case was and where exactly in my body the cancer was. We were so convinced we had caught it early, I felt normal, no side effects, my electrolyte and metabolic panels all came back within normal range. Looking at me, you never would have guessed.On my 21st Wedding Anniversary, July 5th, my family and I went to Kaiser and received the devastating prognosis. I have stage 4 Metastatic Adenocarcinoma, and it has spread throughout my body. It is in the lymph nodes throughout my body, my mediastinum, esophageal junction, my liver, pancreas, stomach, lower hip bones, and my pelvic bones. The doctor told me that without treatment that I have 6 months, up to a year. I have always had a positive outlook on life. I’ve always promoted the whole power of intention, power of attraction, the secret, etc. So naturally I’m trying to think positive, but I have to admit, I am super scared. I don’t know what my future holds. All I know is that I am not ready to leave this world.After some research we found that in my case, chemotherapy would only increase my presumed time by 5%. So this is my plea for help. I have found that there are cures for cancer in other countries, treatments that are not made available here in the United States. Since they are treatments not offered here, my insurance will not cover it. That is where this GoFundMe comes into play. Please help me with my cause, anything helps, even a dollar, whatever you can afford. I want to help in finding the cure, make a difference, and tell my story to the world. I’ve never been one to give up, so I’m not about to start now!

title: Medical Expense for Joel & Alan
text: Would you join us to raise funds to meet the medical expense of Joel & Alan Koshy. On June 24th of 2018, Joel & Alan (twins) met with a terrible accident at Waco, Texas. Both the twins were rushed to the nearby  hospital to get immediate care and later on airlifted to Baylor Scott &White hospital at Temple, Texas as they were in critical condition. Both of them have endured multiple surgeries and are recuperating. Alan still needs to go through another critical surgery on his cervical spine. Its been almost three weeks that have been hospitalized and are still in  intensive care so the expenses are piling up. As you can imagine the emotional stress their family is going through to see their loved ones fight the odds. The medical expenses will weigh quite heavily on the family. Please consider donating, and if not, please pray! We are grateful for your prayer and support!If you would like to give another means, feel free to use the following: Venmo: @oomenkoshy1- Family & Friends!

title: Helping Avril Fight Cancer
text: Avril Currier is an artist and carpenter living in Alpine, WY and working in Jackson.  He started having back pains and within one month was life-flighted to Salt Lake City and within 48 hours he had surgery on his cervical spine and had a tumor removed.  Due to the damage the tumor caused , Ave is paralyzed from the chest down and does not have motor control of his fingers.  He was just diagnosed as having EGFR Lung Cancer which has spread to other organs.  Ave is now undergoing physical therapy, radiation in the cervical spine, and waiting to be approved for the cancer drug Afatinib.Currently his wife Deborah, my sister, has been with him 24/7 since this devastating tragedy and has not been able to work or go home.  Therefore the money is desperately needed now for basic living and medical expenses.If you cannot donate we appreciate your prayers for this urgent situation.   Please spread the message.Avril and Deborah send you their love.

title: Let's help Kim fight Lymphoma
text: Dear Family & Friends, The unexpected happens. And it can change everything. As many as you may know our beloved Kim Klonaris was diagnosed with lymphoma this July, shortly after she was in Nassau caring for her mother who is currently battling breast cancer. It was a heavy blow. At 42, and in excellent health, no one could have ever imagined this would be a part of Kim’s journey. Naturally, the family has been completely thrown into a whirlwind. The lymphoma is Marginal zone low grade b-cell non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma and requires aggressive chemotherapy treatments - including some hospitalization. We are so grateful because the prognosis is good. However, Kim had to make the very hard decision for her to leave her precious 8 year old daughter Eleni, husband Charles, family, church and friend support system as well as her home and begin rigorous chemo and medical treatments in the US for the next two and a half months. Kim and Charles run a small airfreight business on island and now Kim is unable to work. Insurance covers some of her treatment but not all costs. Some of her cancer medicines out of hospital are not covered nor is travel, food and accommodation costs for family members who will be looking after Kim. In just over two short months, Charles and Kim have spent well over 10K out of pocket. Anyone who has faced a similar battle knows only too well how quickly it all adds up. Kim and family have been long time members of the Lucayan Presbyterian Kirk and have always generously supported charitable causes in our wonderful Freeport Community. She and her family are so kind and humble, always giving. She and her family have never asked … nor will they ever ask … for help, even though they need it. Sometimes, though, we have to stand in the gap. So, on behalf of all of Kim and Charles’ family, friends and all who have asked how they can help, I’m asking. This is going to be a very tough battle for Kim and her family. Physically, emotionally and financially. Tremendous love and support are needed. So true to the village we Grand Bahamians truly are, there have been many calls, emails, texts, prayers and messages of love and support. Many have asked how they can help and, for those in a position to do so, a donation is a tangible way to help them in the journey ahead. Every donation, in any amount, helps and is so very much appreciated. We are grateful for whatever help you can give – donation or otherwise. Most importantly, please keep the prayers coming - Kim is so strong in her faith and has found great comfort in all the prayers, love and support she has already received…thank you! The unexpected does happen. Amazingly, in the midst of the toughest battles come the most extraordinary – and unexpected - displays of faith, strength, perseverance, support and love. And, that changes everything. Please feel free to share this post to your Facebook page in an effort to get the word out. Let’s support our sweet Kim and let her focus on getting better. Thanking you all so much in advance!! SHE’S GOT THIS! #KIMMIESTRONG!

title: The Wickman/Judd Family
text: On Saturday evening May 5th, 2018 a tragic accident occurred in our close-knit community. The life of 7 year old Kaillen Mykenna Wickman was taken from her beautiful family far too soon, during a boating accident in the piscataqua river. Her younger brother Michael Brian Wickman ‘Mikey’, is currently at Boston children’s hospital, while he is being treated for injuries due to the accident. No family should have to bare the thought, yet alone action of laying to rest there own child, while standing strong for another. If you can please help by donating and, or sharing it would be greatly appreciated.Please also keep the Wickman/Judd Family in your thoughts & prayers, as well as a quick recovery for little Mikey. Thank you. May you Rest In Peace Kaillen❤️1/7/11-5/5/2018

title: Jim's Fight for Life
text: Our dear friends, Jim & Annette Bradley learned just this week that they are facing unexpected months of intensive medical treatment. As Christian brothers and sisters we have a unique way to help “Carry each other’s burdens” as they face uncertain times.On March 23, 2018 Jim was diagnosed with carcinoma in the base of his tongue over two inches wide with metastasis to nearby lymph nodes. This was after just a few weeks of some headaches, a sudden painful lump in his neck, and problems swallowing.  He is currently under the care of a team of specialists who are assessing the treatment regimens available.  He has completed a full body PET Scan and results will be forthcoming about the extent of any metastasis below his neck.  He had minor surgery March 26 to assist in the diagnosis and will again undergo surgery April 2 to install a chemotherapy port in his chest.  Daily radiation is planned for 6 to 7 weeks along with chemotherapy at various intervals.  Monday April 9th has been targeted for the beginning of radiation and chemo therapies. He has been told he will lose up to 80 pounds and it may become necessary for a feeding tube to be installed in his abdomen. Even at this point, before any treatment, he is in significant pain and is on measured amounts of morphine around-the-clock as well as hydrocodone.As you can imagine, Jim has quite a rocky road of therapy and healing ahead of him. The treatments and the side effects that go along with them dictate that he will have to cut back on much of his work during the next 6 to 8 months.  The oncologist has prepared him for a potentially longer period of adjustment as there are simply too many unknowns to be precise at this point.  Some of you are aware of Jim’s history of heart disease and heart attack and his success in overcoming of those trials.  Now he is facing the battle for his life.Between the expenses of the planned treatment and reduced capability to work, several of his friends have encouraged this GoFundMe campaign. You can imagine one of the many unrelenting stresses for Jim and Annette will be these questions: how can we go forward financially? With no disability insurance, how can we pay our bills? Can we afford the right therapies? Can we continue paying our insurance premiums?  Can we meet the ever-rising deductible? – the list is endless.Yet this is one area where we ALL can come together and help relieve some of these nagging concerns. With your donation we can let Jim & Annette focus on healing and living – and not waste precious emotional energy on finances. They have already begun steps to simplify their lives. Jim realizes this will be a defining life moment and will likely change the course of it. Simplicity will be good. So, they are making meaningful changes already:  they recognize the dire necessity of drastically cutting living expenses, including the possible sale of of their home in the future.  They have already begun to sell several possessions while at the same time assessing future work realities – all with an eye toward a healthier, less stressful, future.   Over the years they have been supportive, welcoming, friends to so many of us in Texas, Alabama, Mississippi, North Carolina, Arkansas, and, of course, Memphis. As we all pray for the Father to bless Jim and Annette with healing, each of us also has an opportunity to contribute in a meaningful way to relieve some of their concern in this most anxious time. You may support Jim & Annette with cards and well wishes sent directly to them through Facebook messenger.Thank you for supporting Jim & Annette with your continued prayers over this extended time. Scott MillsWinston-Salem, NC Blair BryanCharlotte, NC  "Let us not become weary in doing good, for at the proper time we will reap a harvest if we do not give up. Therefore, as we have opportunity, let us do good to all people, especially to those who belong to the family of believers. Galatians 6:9-10"

title: Teaching Cancer a Lesson by Kellie
text: Kellie Ryan is a 26 year old kindergarten teacher who at the start of 2018 had seen a number of life changes.  She moved in to her first apartment, had a new car, and adopted a rescue dog.  She loved her job, her kindergarten kids, and life in general was going very well for her.  Sadly, things quickly changed.  On January 15, a routine blood test had anything but routine results.  She was awakened by a 2:00 AM phone call from her doctor saying she was critically anemic and missing half of her body's blood.  A trip to the ER resulted in a prescription, which caused severe abdominal distention and pain.  Another ER trip resulted in another prescription that accomplished nothing.  A return to the ER that same day caused Kellie to be admitted to the hospital, where she would remain for 12 days.  The last of numerous exams and tests determined Kellie's situation was caused by a large abdominal mass.  Emergency surgery was performed and lab testing determined she had Stage 4 colon cancer.Several days later Kellie left the hospital and has had the first of what will be many chemotherapy treatments.  Her life is now anything but normal, and a far cry from where it was just a few weeks ago.  She and her family met with cancer experts from USC and UCLA who recommended specialized testing and more probable surgeries.  She was placed on disability, resulting in a substantial decrease in her paycheck.  Sadly she also had to return her dog to the rescue foundation as she was unable to physically care for him.   Kellie will undergo more chemo sessions, blood testing, exams, meetings with expert doctors, and additional surgeries.  She badly needs genetic testing to try and determine why a healthy 26 year old, with no family history of colon cancer, has been stricken with this disease.  Sadly, her insurance has denied coverage for that urgently needed test. Your donations will immediately be used to pay for this genetic test that could determine the best course of action to treat her cancer. This will hopefully help get her back into class with her kindergarten kids, who she misses so much.  Kellie is and will be facing expensive medical bills in addition to her rent, car payments, insurance and other expenses.  She has never been one to ask for help unless it's absolutely necessary.  Any and all money received in this Go Fund Me account will be used for the current, pending, and future expenses not covered so she may continue to lead a semi-normal life while trying to get the treatment and help she needs.  In keeping with her love for kids, Kellie has determined any and all unneeded funds will be donated to St. Jude's Children's Hospital, so others even younger than she will also get the help they need and deserve.      Kellie, her family, and friends thank you in advance for all of your support.

title: Amy Short-Ashworth - Adrenal Cancer
text: Where to start…I Need Help!!!I find myself in one crazy situation. I am a 44 year old mother of three children (JJ-5, Nyah-9, and Izzy-17). I need HELP!!! I’m trying to raise $300,000.000, half of which I  need ASAP for a deposit. I desperately need a surgery, Hyperthermic Intraperitoneal Chemotherapy, known as HIPEC. HIPEC is an up and coming surgery to treat different forms of abdominal cancers. I have a very rare and aggressive form of ADRENAL CANCER called Adrenal Cortical Carcinoma (ACC).  ACC is called a “Terrorist” cancer, an “Orphan” cancer. ACC is relentlessly aggressive and extremely rare. I have limited treatment options and very little time. I have been battling with ACC for 2 years. I am statistically approaching the end of my road. My Oncologist and I have exhausted every conventional form of treatment for my ACC. We started with surgery combined with radiation therapy and it returned in less than 2 months. After my recurrence in July of 2017, we hit it with almost a year of intense chemotherapy. A 3 chemo cocktail that has left me disabled and suffering from a pulmonary embolism. The embolism ended my remaining systemic chemo treatments. My tumors have responded well to the chemo, and there has been significant shrinkage, but the 4 tumors are still in the peritoneal lining of my abdomen. During HIPEC, what is left of my tumors will be removed, then Dr. Miller will apply heated chemo directly into my abdomen. I will be the very first ACC patient to be treated with HIPEC at the University of Michigan Cancer Center.  This treatment can give me years instead of months. Without this surgery, I will not live long enough to see my two youngest children finish grade school. I have insurance, my husband and I purchased our heath insurance through the ACA Marketplace, and I am grateful to the ACA. Without its protections for pre-existing conditions I wouldn’t have had the last 2 years with my family. Unfortunately, treatments provided out of network and out of state ARE NOT COVERED. Like I said before, my cancer is extremely rare and very aggressive, less than one in a million rare, and only three surgeons in the United States perform this surgery for ACC patients. I have started this Go Fund Me page because, like I said, my insurance won’t cover this cancer-busting procedure, and I am running out of time.With your help in funding this surgery, to be done by the ADRENAL CANCER research team at University of Michigan, HIPEC is my opportunity and small window to be with my family for hopefully many more years. I have hope, my family has hope, that I can actually beat this cancer, but soon the tumors will become too large and HIPEC will no longer be a viable option.  We are not a family to easily ask for help, but cancer changes your perspective on many things. Please help us by donating. Every little bit helps in a big way.FINANCIAL GOAL:Our financial goal is $300,000.00. A jaw dropping amount of money, but the surgery is expensive. Your donations in any amount will help cover the following:-Travel expenses between Phoenix, Arizona & Ann Arbor, Michigan-HIPEC Surgery, a 12-14 hour surgery-8 to10 days in the ICU and the hospital-Follow up visits for 2 weeks after my release from U of M, with my ACC specialist, Dr. Gary Hammer, and my surgeon, Dr. Barbra Miller. -Medication,Tests, and imaging-Accommodations for myself and my family for 4 to 5 week stay in Ann Arbor   -Paid help for me, and childcare for Nyah and JJ, as recovery is estimated at 6-9 months.

title: Help the Adamo Family
text: The Adamo Family needs our help! This gofundme account has been created to help with funeral, medical and just all expenses as they navigate this incredibly difficult time in their lives. Update from Sarah: Today (Thursday) at about 1:50 PM Mountain time, Jacob met his creator face to face. I have no words, no emojis to give. My soul is numb. His body didn't want to go anymore and things started failing.I have one more request... pray for wisdom and the wherewithal to get through the next few days. There will be lots of decisions to be made.I'm headed home to love on my babies. And to tell them how much their Daddy loved them. ❤ Thank you for your prayers and support during this time. As soon as we have a date for his service, I will let you all know. ❤From Sarah: April 8, 2018 Update on Jacob... went to the ER... and he had some blood tests. For those nerdy friends his bilibuben level was 39...and his creatinine was at 8 (.5 to 1 is normal for his age). The doc said he needed a specialist (hepatologist) so he is en-route to Denver (UC Health in Aurora) ICU via ambulance where he is getting a CT scan. The pic is him just leaving the ER for the ambulance. I am on my way down with Thea (his mom). We will then get an official diagnoses.How am I? Wrecked. My birthday is tomorrow and our 15th anniversary is Thursday and the worst case stuff discussed in the ER were things like "kidney failure" and "transplant". Not the words you want to hear.The kids are at home being cared for. I am going to try and keep Mike Marlow updated as to his condition and for those that are local Leslie Marshall has set up a Meal Train (  https://mealtrain.com/68g4nk ) and a fundraiser to help with travel expenses. You can also reach out to Thea Adamo or Sherma Cundall if you cannot get ahold of me right away.Please pray for answers and for healing, for my sanity, and for our kids as we walk this out. I don't know how long I'm going to be down in Denver with him... just all the nitty gritty details are up in the air right now. Thank you so much to everyone who have already jumped in. I'm so thankful for you.I will update as soon as I know more.

title: Support The Dietz Family
text: On Sunday, August 12th, Derek Dietz unexpectedly went into Cardiac Arrest. He is currently in ICU and fighting for his life. Derek has a wife (Katie) and two small children (Jaxson and Peyton). Anyone who has had the pleasure of knowing Derek, knows what a great guy he is and how he would do absolutely anything for anyone. He is a doting husband, father, son, brother and friend. We’re putting this page together to help the Dietz family with unforeseen medical expenses and just expenses in general since Derek is obviously unable to work. Katie hasn’t left his side and therefor also is unable to work. Anything you are able to contribute to help them out would be greatly appreciated! Let’s all pray for a speedy recovery for Derek! You’ve got this Dietz

title: Duane Wallace
text: As many of you are aware, we recently received sad news regarding our beloved friend Duane (Dewey) Wallace.  Duane is battling cancer and going through treatment.Duane has been the lead staff member in the Locker House.  He has not only trained many of the young men who have worked there over the years, but set the culture for what makes each one of us feel so special when we walk through those doors. His absence is palpable. Duane is a key-stone in the Kirtland family and has had a large impact on each of us whether known or unknown. We feel that it would be a great gesture of gratitude and huge help to Duane and his family if we could pitch in to help him through this difficult process. We are all thinking good thoughts, but also know that any monetary help  we can provide would make a difference and mean a lot to Duane and his family.  All donations will be pooled and given to Duane on behalf of the membership.We appreciate your consideration. Thank you,Sam Ahuja and Woods King

title: Team Lani
text: https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/fight-song/1061182666?i=1061182684 Typically a post containing the name Fred Bachmann and Xiomara Bachmann is  filled with exciting training sessions, soccer tournament wins/highlights and wrestling championships.  This one is a bit different.  Their daughter Xiolani, who we all know as vivacious and energetic, a real hustler out on the soccer field and an all around sweet-natured kid is battling an illness that we still do not have a diagnosis for.  It is with a heavy heart that we write this message about Lani.  This young lady is in the fight of her life right now.  Lani has not been able to walk or talk for over a week and is currently at Dupont Hospital.  Fred and Xiomara were informed on Sunday that their 8 year old girl was being admitted to the intensive care unit and Lani would have to immediately start an invasive procedure call plasmapheresis in order to stabilize her condition.  The entire Bachmann community-family, friends, colleagues and sports community is devastated by this news.  Fred and Xiomara will be out of work for an extended period of time and their income is going to be drastically reduced as a result.  Unfortunately, the long term recovery for Lani will take months and her parents will have to miss a lot of work to support her recovery once the doctors stabilize her condition.  We have decided to start a Go Fund Me page for Lani.  Fred and Xiomara have no idea as they would certainly not allow it to be done.  Anyone who knows them knows they are not the type to ask for anything.  We have all watched Fred train wrestlers and soccer players over the years and never ask for a penny nor recognition. I know, from private conversations, he truly looks at these kids and parents as extended family members.  He truly loves watching all kids succeed-not just his own.  Xiomara has opened up her home to many families throughout the year and has willingly picked up the duties at home when Fred was spending a great deal of time helping others.  Lani, Fred and Xiomara are in need of all of our help.  Many loved ones are offering support in many ways and the last week has been incredible to see in terms of how good people can be when a family is brought to their knees.   The financial cushion that we are trying to raise will allow Fred and Xiomara to focus on Lani without the stress of worrying about finances.Lani is an incredible  soccer player who has excelled on the field as well as in the classroom.  Her smile is infectious and her good natured spirit has touched many.  She will beat this illness and come back stronger than ever!!!

title: Relief for the Humpherys/Boyd
text: *UPDATE: Sweet Emily passed away early this morning ( 06/01) due to her injuries. We are all devastated by her death. On Sunday May 27th, our dear friend Anne Humpherys along with her two granddaughters Emily (8) and Hannah (6) were hit by a driver under the influence. This resulted in the death of Anne Humpherys and left Emily at Loma Linda hospital on life support. Luckily, Hannah left without any injury. We are trying to raise donations as a way to ease the burdens placed upon the Humpherys/Boyd family. These donations will be used for funeral services and medical bills and other recovery expenses. Anything you can give will make a difference!

title: #B11Strong
text: As some of you know, our Principal at LBHS, Dr. Trent Daniel, discovered last week that her son, Britton has a rare form of bone cancer. Britton is a senior at Oviedo High School, where he excels in academics as well as athletics. He will need to undergo 12 months of treatment beginning this week. Trent and her family will make countless trips to Gainesville, as well as accrue monumental medical expenses. Here’s how you can help:1. Donate. Remember, no amount is too small.2. Share this on social media3. Email friends this linkThank you and God Bless Britton

title: Jimmy Rumer Brain Cancer
text: Funds raised will go towards taking financial pressure off this young hard working family in this time of great need and heartache. Jim and Michelle have always been first to put their hands up to help others both through not-for-profit Organizations and on personal levels. Now is our chance  to truly help them.

title: Champions for Jody
text: ￼￼For those of you that that may not know on 3/26 Jody Brue had a debilitating stroke that caused a massive brain bleed that has affected the right side of his brain. Subsequently, he required a lifesaving surgery where the doctors had to remove part of the skull to allow his brain to swell without causing any more damage. Currently he has limited movement on the left side of his body, but he was able to say his name and give his wife Cara a high five. He has a feeding tube but hopefully it will come out soon!!  The next step is at least 6 more weeks in the hospital, an intense couple of weeks of stroke therapy at an inpatient facility and most likely followed by an extended stay in a professional nursing facility where he will continue therapy until he is able to go home. We have a very long road ahead of us, but Jody has an AMAZING, MAGICAL, UNBELIEVEABLE group of friends and family that surrounds him.  With all that said, even with insurance medical bills can be a HUGE financial burden. From doctor’s bills, insurance co-pays, and LOST WAGES we are increasing our gofundme goal to go towards financial assistance to meet Jody’s family needs! We are grateful for all the donations so far. Even if you are not able to donate we ask you to share this link so others can help and share the love.  We cannot thank each and everyone of you enough. We are truly blessed to have the support we do. More about our dear friend Jody Brue: Jody is 43 years young and has shared an amazing 18 years with his wife Cara.  He is also blessed with 2 beautiful kids, McKay 17 and Zoe 16. He is such a positive and encouraging person that always has a smile to give. Please help us support this amazing family. #BrueCrewStrong

title: For Judy and Brian Hale
text: Behind every great man stands an even greater woman and some woman rarely takes credit for everything her husband has accomplished.  That last part is not Judy.  She is very vocal for being the rock that has made Brian a great man; our mentor, our coach, our teammate, our brother, and our hero.  Joking aside, for everything that Brian has done for us we have Judy to thank.  It is her endless support and love for Brian that allows him to give back to the community.  This time Judy and Brian need us.Judy was diagnosed with a rare cervical cancer in January.  Despite rounds of chemo, the aggressive cancer has spread and doctors have recommended palliative care.  Judy and Brian are continuing to find options for a cure.  It is a tough and grueling journey.  But those who know Judy; she isn't giving up.  Born and raised in the mean streets of Chicago Chinatown, Judy is prepared to fight this.  As friends and families have offered support and prayers, we created this GoFundMe page to help with medical expenses and other costs.  100% of the donations will go entirely to the Hales.  Thank you for your generosity!  Please leave a note or favorite story of Judy.  We will forward all messages to Judy and Brian.  If you ever had the chance to watch Judy and Brian look at each other, you see the truest of love.  22 years of being together.  22 years of love, laughter, and 12 years of being husband and wife.  Behind every great man stands an even greater woman.  Judy: our mentor, our coach, our teammate, our sister, and our hero.

title: Help cure Andrew's Leukemia
text: My name is Suzanne Tieder and I'm the proud aunt and godmother to Andrew Trouts - my loving, joyful three year old nephew. I'm here to ask you for your prayers and help as Andrew begins his brave journey to fight and BEAT Burkitt's Leukemia. Just three weeks ago, Melissa and Chris took Andrew to their pediatrician to diagnose and treat a lump on the side of his face. After two rounds of antibiotics and several stumped doctors, Andrew was admitted to the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP). Days later, a battery of tests confirmed that he has stage four blood cancer.  Andrew received the first of many upcoming chemo treatments on Friday, March 30. Because the cancer is aggressive, doctors have put him on a chemo treatment plan that will last six to eight months, with most of his  time being spent at CHOP. We are optimistic that at the end of Andrew's journey, he will stand tall, proud, victorious and ready to continue his life as a survivor. In order for Melissa and Chris to provide the full time care and love so critical to Andrew's healing process, they need to work reduced hours, thus immediately foregoing their full time salaries for the duration of Andrew's treatment and recovery. To help them cover the lost wages and Andrew's increasing costs of medical care, I am kindly asking for your generosity. Every thought, prayer, positive vibe, and contribution will help Andrew stay strong and WIN. On behalf of the Trouts, Branyans, Tieders, and Andrew's extended family, I sincerely thank you for your show of support and standing by Melissa, Chris and Andrew's brothers, Conner (eight) and William (five) during this trying time. As they say, it takes a village, and in this case, #TeamAndrew. I'll be updating Andrew's gofundme page regularly so we can all keep track of his progress and cheer him on together. If there is a private message you would like me to send to Melissa, Chris, or Andrew, please feel free to do so by connecting with me here. Much love and thanks,SuzanneAndrew just turned three April 1! He's planning his second helping of birthday cake...Andrew was SO exicted to see his brothers, Conner (left) & William (right)! Andrew and his Mr. Potato head crew. :)

title: Gabby Gingras’s Smile
text: Hello, My wife Kaylene and I have never met Gabby yet we remember her from years ago when her story first aired in 2004. We saw Gabby on the news on May 23rd and were again touched by this amazing young woman. We decided to help and set up this GoFundMe page so she can get the smile she deserves! The funds will go to her and her family which will help to pay for the estimated $120,000 in medical costs that her insurance will not cover. View her story at  https://www.kare11.com/video/news/girl-who-cant-feel-pain-battles-insurance-company/89-8138661. Thanks to all of you for your donations and support!

title: Japanese Tourists Brutally Attacked
text: Japanese Tourists Brutally Attacked in Kaka’akoOn Memorial Day, Japanese tourists, Masashige Tamura and his family, were spending what was supposed to be the last day of their dream vacation taking photos of the colorful murals that adorn the streets of Kaka’ako.  Instead a quick stop to use the public bathroom at Mother Waldron Park turned into a nightmare for Masashige and his family.  At this time, he cannot recall much of what happened when he entered the bathroom that day but it is evident he was brutally attacked by at least one person.  He suffers from cracked cheek bones, a cracked skull, deep cuts on his face, dislodged teeth and damaged gums and is obviously deeply traumatized.His wife, Miho Tamura, who ran to the bathroom when she heard the screams, was choked from behind till she passed out.  She suffers from deep cuts on her lips, bruises on her neck and face as well as lasting pain on her entire face.  She too is obviously deeply traumatized.  Somewhat fortunate, their two children (19 and 21years old) were not near them at the time (they were taking photos of the murals) or they may have been assaulted as well.The Tamura’s were rushed to Queen’s Hospital where they were told they would have to be hospitalized for at least 10 days.  Because they were tourists, their insurance would not cover the hospital bill.  The Tamura’s made the difficult decision to fly back to Japan the following day even though Masashige was in no condition to fly.  Back in Japan he could get the proper medical insurance coverage.  He went straight from the airport to the hospital and has been there ever since.  His condition is much worse than anyone imagined but they are glad at least he is still alive.  His next surgery is scheduled for June 9th.To the people of Hawaii, let’s show this family what true Aloha is all about!  This family did not deserve this…no one deserves this!  My name is Shoko and I live in Kaka’ako.  I was visiting Mother Waldron Park that faithful day with my 1 & 5year old daughters when I recognized some Japanese tourists were in distress.  Being raised in Japan, I rushed over to see if I could help.  I ended up translating to the police and doctors for the Tamura’s and taking their children to the hospital and visiting them.  I have remained in touch with them in Japan and really want to do something for them.  100% of the money raised from this site will go to the Tamura Family.  Pease donate anything you can!  No amount is too small!  Thank you!  I as a creator of this page, I will withdraw all the donation and send 100% of it to Tamura Family at my biggest responsibility. The funds will be spent for the medical bills that cannot covered by their insurance, recovery cost they need after surgery, to help with daily expenses until he is able to go back to work, to help to heal their hearts, to help to heal both physically and mentally distressed. Also, please share this with family and friends as a warning that we all must be careful and vigilant of our surroundings.  This could have happened to anyone.  Masashige was truly in the wrong place at the wrong time!ハワイ在住のShokoと申します。2018年5月28日にカカアコ地区で日本人観光客のご家族に起きた暴行事件。私は当時、たまたま子供達を連れて事件の起こった公園に入った時ちょうど事件が起きた直後でした。遠くから見て、男性1人が血まみれで座り込んでおり周りにいた3名の方もパニック状態でいるのがすぐにわかったと同時に日本人観光客とすぐにわかったので、大丈夫ですかと声をかけました。そこから、ご家族と警察、救急隊員、病院のナースなど通訳としてヘルプさせて頂きながら事件の全てそしてご家族の状況を目の当たりにしました。ご家族はハワイ滞在最終日に、最近話題になっているカカアコ地区のウォールアートを見に来ていて、お父様の正茂さんがたまたま入った公園のトイレで事件が起きました。正茂さん曰く、トイレに入って間もなく襲われたそうでその瞬間から記憶が全くありません。様子がおかしい事に気付いた奥様の美穂さんがすぐに確認しようと後を追いましたがトイレに入る直前で別の誰かに背後から首を絞められその場で気絶してしまいました。息子さんと娘さんはこの時幸いにも公園外のウォールアートの写真をとっていて、事件後に駆けつけたそうです。正茂さんと美穂さんは救急車で緊急搬送され、応急処置や検査などを受けた後、約10日間程の入院になりそうと診断されました。正茂さんの怪我の状態:頬の骨陥没おでこ左側深い切り傷歯茎から折られる頭を支える骨にヒビが入った為、髄液が流出両目とも開かない程腫れがる精神的ダメージ美穂さんの怪我の状態:唇の損傷 首、顔面のあざ顔面の痛み精神的ダメージ今すぐにでも手術が必要とされる中、不運にも海外旅行保険に加入されていなかった為に莫大な治療費となってしまい、事件翌日の飛行機で怪我を負ったまま日本へ帰るしかない状況に置かれてしまいました。幸いにも無事に日本に到着し、空港からまっすぐ病院へ向かい、正茂さんは緊急入院となりました。検査の方も進み、思った以に酷い状況であることが発覚し、次の手術予定日が6月9日と決まっています。集まった募金は私が責任を持って100%全て田村さんご家族に送ります。保険適用にならない分のハワイでかかった治療費、病院代、手術後の手当て、心の治療、お仕事に復帰できるようになるまでの日々のコストなど、そしてお見舞金として使われる予定です。私の周りのローカル達が、田村さんご家族の為にたくさんのアロハを送ってあげようと言ってくれて一緒に決めたゴール金額です。せっかくの家族ハワイ旅行でまさかこんな事件にあってしまうなんて、誰も想像すらできません。ハワイ在住の方、日本在住の方、世界中の方々、1円でも構いませんのでどうかサポートして頂けると嬉しいです！募金で集まった金額100%全て田村さんご家族に寄付されます。どうかよろしくお願いいたします。

title: Faiths Final Hope
text: Hello My Name is Renee, I am one of Faith long term friends. Many of you are personal friends of Faith and are familiar with her story and love her dearly. We absolutely need a miracle for Faith in the next couple of weeks. For those of you who have or have not followed Faith’s healing journey here’s what’s happening: Faith needs your financial help! There is nothing more that her Oncologist or Surgeon can do for her, she is in the lates stages of Stage 4 Mestatic Breast Cancer. Because it has already metastasized, ( spread to her spine ) It has the potential to spread very quickly to her major organs, it’s hard to say exactly how long she has. She is in the process of phasing our out of her job, as her health is seemingly declining. We don’t know how long she has, it could be just a series of months. Needless to say she is in need of a miracle. Faith has been accepted as a patient for experimental treatment at CHIPSA Hospital. This treatment will cost $33,427.17 This will cover 3 weeks of inpatient treatment, 3 meals a day, her own room, and covers the cost of an extra room and 3 meals a day for her travel companion. CHIPSA hospital has a lot of long standing integrity with Cancer.  https://chipsahospital.org/Faith has chosen this hospital because of the many first hand reports she has heard through the years in regard to their high results with cancer. CHIPSA has much higher results with cancer treatment for individuals with compromised immune systems........Of these Therapies are two in particular: IPT and the Vallovax Vaccine. IPT is low dose chemo assisted with Insulin, because cancer cells have more insulin receptors on them than healthy cells the chemo bypasses the healthy cells and only kills the cancer cells! Yay ! No hair falling out ! The Vallovax vaccine has received a lot of media coverage lately. 80-95% of clinical trials are seeing cancer patients with late stage disease with a clean bill of health, and with no side effects?! CHIPSAs hospital is only 23 miles south of sandiego, just over the border in Tiujuana. Faith has interviewed with her agent Kim, in addition to Dr Castillo her attending Physician. They have offered her 3 week opening available immediately. She has been approved for a comprehensive late stage cancer treatment program. She is most encouraged about the Vallovax Vaccine , it is anti angiogenic in nature and it is destroying cancer by: “reducing the growth of new blood vessels needed by tumors to grow and metastasize” It basically starves the tumors from their energy source and they die! The hospital is reporting that patients aren’t needing as much IPT because the Vallovax vaccine is having so much substantial success ! Overview- ( for those who need the back story) Faith was Diagnosed in July 2017 with stage 4 Breast Cancer. Faith’s White Blood cell count was dangerously low prior to starting any treatment. Her Oncologist says she has a condition called Leukopenia. This is where your white cell count is so low that even your own bodies bacteria can become dangerous to you. This makes Faith a risky candidate for chemo, Chemo greatly reduces your white blood cell count. Many people do not realize that it’s not the chemo that kills off the entirety of the cancer, it is the immune systems job to do so. I share this to clarify why Faith was never a candidate for typical Cancer therapy. Faith also has had a 9 year history of complicated auto immune diagnoses, there were years when she was so ill she couldn’t work. So now you have a better idea of why she needs to pursue this experimental treatment. Please consider donating or becoming a fundraiser yourself . If 350 people could find a way to raise 100$ from their friends and family , we could knock this out as quickly as possible and potentially save her life ! Sadly this is a life and death situation. We ask that everyone please share this post and more specifically if you would consider being a fundraiser yourself and gathering funds from you’re circle. If we get to the $35,000 mark Faith can go immediately...let’s get it done in three days and save her life!!

title: Miracle of the Heart
text: My name is Adriana Hill, and I am from El Salvador. My nephew, Juan Fernando Salaverria, an 18 year old salvadoran, needs to undergo surgery during the second week of July 2018 and we need your help, besides your empathy and prayers. Juan Fer was born in 1999 withTetralogy of Fallot, absence of pulmonary valve and detached pulmonary artery. There are only a few doctors and hospitals in the world that can, to this day,  perform the surgery because of its complexity.  Dr. Evan Zahn is his doctor (currently based in Cedar Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles)who together with Redmond Burke saved his life in1999. As a matter of fact, his condition was so rareback then and his odds for survival so low, that theMiami Herald published an article about him titled“A miracle of the Heart”. We gave everything forhim, not only emotionally, but also financially.Juan’s birth was supposed to be one of joy, the firstgrandson in our family. His mother was fully covered by insurance, but things changed radically when Juan was born with an undetected congenitaldisease. All of these medical procedureswere out of pocket expenses, since the insurancecompany denied coverage due to his congenitalcondition. After two open heart surgeries andseven catheterisms, plus the loss of sight in one of his eyes he needs another intervention.Two days ago we got the hospital’s quotation for his procedure. $89,000.00 We are not financially prepared for that and are turning to you to support us in finding themanner in which we might raise the necessary funds.  A child’slife, an amazing child’s life is at stake. We beg you, from our hearts,from my families’ and from our country of El Salvador’sprayers, where Juan has been an example of resilience, faithand hope, to help us. These funds will be used to paybfor his procedure  scheduled to bebon July 17 2018 Mi nombre es Adriana Hill y soy de El Salvador. Mi sobrino Juan Fernando Salaverria es un joven de 18 años que nació con Tetralogía de Fallo, ausencia de válvula pulmonar y de una arteria pulmonar. En la segunda semana de julio de este año debe de someterse a un cateterismo para poder reemplazar la válvula pulmonar que actualmente tiene. Solo hay un par de doctores en el mundo que actualmente realizan este procedimiento debido a su complejidad. El Dr. Evan Zahn es el doctor de Juan Fernando (actualmente trabaja en el Cedar Sinaí Hospital de Los Ángeles) quien junto con el Dr. Raymond Burke salvaron la vida de Juan Fernando en 1999. La condición con la que nació Juan Fernando era tan rara y su probabilidad de sobrevivir tan baja que el Miami Herald publicó un artículo sobre  llamado "Un Milagro del Corazón". Desde ese momento sus padres y el resto de su familia han dado todo para sacar adelante a Juan Fer no solo emocionalmente pero también  económicamente. Al momento de nacer, la mamá de Juan Fernando contaba con seguro médico, pero al ser la enfermedad de índole congénita, las cosas cambiaron drásticamente. Todos los procedimientos a los que se ha sometido Juan Fernando han sido pagados al 100% por la familia ya que la aseguradora le negó cobertura alguna. Después de dos cirugías de corazón abierto, siete cateterismos y la perdida completa de un ojo, Juan Fer necesita otra intervención. Hace unos días recibimos la cotización del hospital por el procedimiento $89,000.00.  No estamos preparados económicamente para esta situación por eso buscamos de su apoyo para encontrar la manera de poder ayudar a Juan Fernando. En nombre de nuestra familia agradecemos su apoyo, sus oraciones y su cariño para nuestro Juan Fer. Estos fondos serán destinados para pagar los gastos de su operación programada para el 17 de julio de 2018.

title: Strong for Rowan: Battling Cancer
text: On behalf of Matthew Haynes, Abigail Haynes and family.This page is not intended solely for financial reasons. It may also serve as a platform for those to show love and support to baby Rowan and those who go above and beyond to care for him.  Those who choose to support through V E N M O: @mwhaynesOur fight with cancer: Our son, Rowan, was diagnosed with stage III Ganglioneuroblastoma at 15 months of age on March 2nd, 2018. An intermixed mass of cancerous and benign cells forming a tumor larger than a grapefruit was growing in his pelvis out toward his abdomen.  After two cycles of chemotherapy, the cancer was unresponsive and the only treatment left was surgery. On April 26th, the amazing surgical staff at Miller Children’s Hospital in Long Beach was able to perform a miracle. They took out 90% of the mass even though it was incasing his aorta and inferior vena cava. While considered overly successful, they could not safely remove the mass inside his spinal column and sacrum.Our fight isn’t over:  While the best possible outcome was achieved during surgery, our battle with cancer is far from complete. Depending on the type of tissue that still remains in his body and how well he recovers from surgery, he will still need a lot of treatment. He might need additional chemotherapy and maybe even radiation. Rowan will eventually need physical, occupational, and speech therapy to catch up on his milestones. Our oncology team estimates that his treatment will take anywhere from 6-12 months; we have been in the pediatric intensive care unit for only two months so far. As of April 28, 2018, he is still fighting hard in the surgical recovery stage of his treatment roadmap.Why we need your support: Plainly stated, we want to be able to ensure Rowan is being well taken care of. We also want to be able to support those who go out of their way to care for him. Rowan requires us to be by his side at all times in the hospital so we won’t be actively earning income. These donations will help us maintain his care and comfort. My awesome employer has given my family so much already, but those amazing benefits cannot last forever. All monies donated will be used for the treatment, care, comfort, and support of Rowan and those who care for him.For more detailed information on our son’s condition and treatment, scroll down for the whole story.The Haynes Family thanks you from the bottom of our hearts!Feel free to contact me at matthewhaynes@kpmg.com or mhaynes15@yahoo.com￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼The Story: We took Rowan to our pediatrician on March 1st, 2018 because he was being extremely fussy during the past week. He wouldn’t eat, sleep, or crawl. Rowan would just whimper instead. We thought it was an ear ache and teething but our doctor was more concerned about how bloated his belly was. She ordered tests: blood, stool, and an ultrasound.  Later that evening around 7 o’clock, we got a call from her telling us to go to the ER because Rowan's lab results were extremely abnormal. Most notably, his calcium was >15mg/dL (Severe hypercalcemia). That trip to the ER would change our lives forever.￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼Soon after we get to the ER, an abdominal ultrasound revealed that he had a huge mass growing in his belly.  We were admitted to the Pediatric ICU. From there, as if almost on cue, he started to developed severe diarrhea. He would end up losing about 3 to 4 liters of stool everyday.  Confounded by what could be causing the stooling, the PICU team could only treat the extreme electrolyte imbalances and dehydration until the MRIs would reveal what was truly inside. After a week, the MRI was presented to us by the pediatric oncology team. The mass was a lot larger than expected and appeared to be growing from his sacrum to his belly button; it was 12x10x12cm. It was compressing his stomach and bladder, and pushing his intestines toward his ribs. Tumor and bone marrow biopsies needed to be taken in order to give us a definitive diagnoses. Our worst fears came to fruition.￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼The diagnosis was Ganglioneuroblastoma: Stage III Cancer.  It is a very rare cancer that has benign and malignant growths intermixed. The cancer was also emitting a hormone (vasoactive intestinal polypeptide) that caused him to have severe diarrhea; even if he had nothing to eat or drink, he would still have watery stool. At the time, the edpidemiologists thought the dysentery was from a contagious disease, so Rowan was put on isololation for most of the time. In essence, he was forced to stay in his crib for weeks, which was horrible. The diarrhea posed a huge challenge because it resulted in Rowan having his blood tested every four hours so that they could replace his electrolytes and fluids. Eventually, he had to have a semi-permanent central line placed under his collar bone for easy access to blood and meds. He also had a feeding tube inserted through his nostril.￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼The plan of attack was to have two cycles of chemotherapy then check to see if the tumor had shrunk. Surgery would have been the first option but the surgical team was worried that the tumor was too vascular (bloody) and chemotherapy would hopefully kill some of the vasculature.  So, we treated the cancer with two rounds. A total of 42 days worth of inpatient therapy in the pediatric oncology ward. Eventually, Rowan's instability would bring us back to the Pediatric ICU where we would call home for most of the stay. They treated him as well they could.￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼After the first round of chemotherapy, preliminary signs indicated that the tumor was not shrinking and everything we did to slow the stooling wasn't working. We continued to give his second round of chemotherapy with different drugs to ensure that we covered all angles. After many blood transfusions, anti-nausea/pain medications, and diaper changes later, we finally take another MRI to see the results of chemo. In short, the results were not good. The MRI indicated that the tumor was unresponsive and actually grew just a few CMs. This was a hard pill to swallow. What was even more devastating was the MRI revealed that the tumor mass was incasing the two main arteries from the heart. The tumor was also being fed blood by three other arteries. This news was devastating to us. The only bright side was that flu restrictions were lifted and Rowan’s big sister, McKenzie, got to see him for the first time after two months.￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼The remaining treatment was surgery; to get as much of the mass out of him as possible. The problem was that removing the mass could be lethal and that only 50% could be taken out safely.  On April 26, 2018 Rowan endured a 6.5 hour surgery that required every pediatric surgeon in the hospital. We were told that 5 surgeons worked simultaneously on him. We were blessed and relieved that a miracle was performed that day and 90% of the tumor was removed. Everyone's prayers and support and love and kindness were answered. Tears of joy were shed by family, nurses, and doctors alike that day. But our battle is far from over. Only a few days into his recovery we are seeing the struggle that remains. He has a long road ahead with treatment to follow. ￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼We will keep you all updated!Thank you from the very bottom of our hearts.

title: Help Mary with ALS Medical Expenses
text: The last year has made Mary and I realize just how unpredictable life is and that you should be grateful for every day...In 2016, Mary had dropfoot and was limping. They could not figure out why and did a spinal surgery thinking that was it. She kept getting weaker and had a fall in Dec 2016, breaking her ankle in three places. In early 2017, she continued losing mobility and by September she could no longer stand. In September, they finally gave us the diagnosis but it was definitely not what we were hoping for...it is ALS (also known as Lou Gehrig’s disease). They say the average lifespan from the first symptoms is 2-4 years and we can definitely see the progression as she is almost bed bound 24/7. But Mary is still dedicated to trying to ‘Stephen Hawking‘ the crap outta this!The cost of paying for a full time caregiver is pretty incredible and we are still on the waiting list to get Medicare to pay for some of it.
