In addition to Mary's healthcare costs, she has started her inevitable decline, being mostly bedbound every day, losing the use of even her hands, and now her voice is becoming difficult to understand clearly. She also is needing respiration in order to sleep and keep oxygen flowing properly.  Ted has to work during the day to keep the ship afloat.  And after buying a handicapped van in October, the medical expenses are starting to mount again for us.If you are in a position to help, it is super appreciated.  We are thankful that we have a full lifetime to remember together.  Living in London, helping her get into Stanford, working at our startup GoTo together, years of watching our kids grow up. Now that she has pretty much only her memories left, we are dedicated to helping her as much as we are able. Thank you her friends and family for all of the laughter and memories.  Mary is dedicated to helping others even in this difficult time - and we've put together a blog with all her lists of life tips .  Check it out!You can also check out this amazing video that a close friend had made at our Team Mary party.  It's a very touching way to see how Mary has touched all our lives.Sending love from Mary.

title: Support the Barvinchak Family
text: Amanda is diagnosed with osteosarcoma. At this time, she will be undergoing treatment at UCLA. Funds raised will go toward her care, and expenses for her family during the time of her treatment. Her diagnosis is in the very early stages, so we will keep you up to date.Amanda Barvinchak is a 24 year old that has been living life to the fullest since day 1. She has always been active, healthy, and excelled in every area of life. Her favorite flower is the sunflower which is so fitting for her because she is truly the sunshine in so many peoples’ lives. Amanda was currently enrolled and on her way to becoming a naturopath doctor. She wanted to help people naturally improve their lives so that they may be healthier and live more prosperously. 5 years ago, she beat bone cancer in her left leg,  now that cancer is back and she needs our support. This time it has come back as a mass on the outside of her lung, causing her intense pain due to all the nerve endings in that area of the body. The doctors believe that it is is localized to that area, but are recommending some rather intensive chemotherapy options as well as large scale surgeries to get her back to her healthy. Although it hurts feeling like we cannot do anything to help her, there actually is a means of assistance.... By supporting her through this fundraiser and sharing this with your network, this will tremendously help her by allowing her parents and loved ones provide all the accommodations for her through this process. There will be many medical costs to get her through this. There is not a person out there that does not shower Amanda with praises on her soft heart and loving outlook on life, it is time we show her our appreciation and support through this hard time. Amanda is a fighter, has made it through this before, and we believe in her to make it through this again.Thank you for your continued support and remember to share this opportunity to support Amanda to your network.

title: To show support for our Kelly!
text: If you have been directed to this GoFundMe, then you are aware that our Kelly has been diagnosed with de novo Stage IV Breast Cancer.  Although we all have the greatest faith that Kelly will continue to be her awesome self and respond well to treatment,  there is still the reality that the appointments, scans, medications and changes in work schedule can take a financial toll.Many people have asked how they can help, and one important way to help Kelly and her family maintain normalcy is to make sure that these expenses do not cause unwelcome worry or derail them from enjoying their family time.Please join us in making a donation towards these expenses and show Kelly how much we love and support her!

title: Beniam Terefe's healthcare
text: On the evening of the 21st August, I lost my best friend and my brother Beni.  No words can convey the loss of such a wonderful person, who will no longer be part of our lives. Beni has left a giant hole that will be felt by all of us who have had the privilege of knowing him.   His loving family, Nolliyae, Adam, Tsehay and Teri have lost a friend, a brother, a son and a gentle soul.  I thank you all from the bottom of my heart for your generosity and continued prayers for the whole family as they go through this difficult time.It is heart-warming to know that he has left an indelible mark on all our lives.Beni my brother, may you rest in peace.Henock.=============================================================================Benji's family will be receiving friends and family at the Ethiopian Community Development Council (ECDC) located at 901 S Highland St. (Basement)Arlington VA 22204 on:Saturday 8/25 : 2pm - 7pmCANCELLED -- Sunday     * Please note - parking garage available in ECDC building *The funeral service is to take place on Monday, 8/27 at 10am in St. Peter Catholic Church located at 313 2nd St. SE, Washington DC 20003 (Capitol Hill)  NOTE: Since there is very limited parking near the church, we recommend either getting a taxi, using public transport (Capital South Metro Station which is two minutes walk from the church) or car pooling and arriving early.The burial is at 12:30 in Rock Creek Cemetery, 201 Allison St NW, Washington, DC 20011  Lunch at Ethiopian Community Development Council (ECDC) located at 901 S Highland St. (Basement)Arlington VA 22204 following burialFor questions, call Rodas at 202-820-0908 or Karine 571-338-9795=============================================================================Beni  is a son, a brother, and a friend to many.  Anyone who has met him knows how genuine, loving , considerate, hardworking and funny he is. Unfortunately he is suffering from stage 4 lung cancer which has spread to his brain, and bones.  He has been valiantly fighting it since January 2018.   Over the past few months, he has been subjected to chemotherapy, radiation, and is now undergoing immunotherapy treatment.Benji is the most decent human being I know,  and a breath of fresh air as anyone who had the pleasure of spending time with him could testify.  He is surrounded by friends and family, and his mother has been taking care of him day and night since he was first diagnosed.   A heartbreaking experience that no parent should have to go through. To make the situation more difficult, his medical insurance will not cover all the extensive treatments and care that he is and will be undergoing.He needs as many people as possible, to include him in their prayers, and to the extent possible, donate to lessen some of the financial stress related to medical expenses, outpatient treatment, in home care, and other unforeseen medical bills  (an unnecessary burden) when he should be focusing on getting better.Please do NOT share this campaign on social media.

title: David Butler Medical Expenses
text: The Short Version:Coach/Sensei/Friend David Butler's Cancer has returned - and as strong, as tough, and as spiritual as this incredible human being is, both he and his family need our help - and God knows he would never ask for it.  With that in mind, he does not know I've created this GoFundMe.  The reason we are raising money for the Butler family is because he'll be spending the next 6+ months going through a combination of radiation and hormone therapy to hopefully combat the cancerous cells.  As you can imagine, this is not an inexpensive process.  Add to that the fact that he owns his own business and is not covered by a corporate healthcare policy.  For someone like Coach Butler; a man who has spent his entire life serving others - it's hard to know how we can help him in perhaps his darkest hour.   Perhaps helping to take the weight of the impending medical expenses off his shoulders will be a good start. What I do know is this: there are few people in this world outside of my family whom I would jump in front of a train for.  Coach Butler is one of them.  Let's make this happen.Tim McMahonUNH Wrestling '99 - '03

title: Support for Baby Olivia Faith Solis
text: On February 22, 2018 Olivia Rene Solis was born to Miguel and Jacqueline (Nortman)Solis. From shortly after that time, Olivia has been in the neonatal ICU as a result of a congenital heart defect. In her short life she has already experienced two major heart procedures and received CPR for over an hour, and continues to fight for her life. Through this time, Olivia’s parents have been surrounded by friends, praying for them constantly, as they hope for a miracle. Olivia was baptized in the ICU and the family gave her the baptismal name, Faith. Miguel and Jacqueline are deeply grateful for all of the prayers and support that are pouring in from all over the world. While their request is simply for continued prayer, the reality is that the costs are mounting. Olivia is receiving the best of care, and it comes at quite the cost. As friends of Miguel and Jacqueline, we ask you to lend your financial support to the overwhelming costs of hospital care for Olivia Faith Solis, as well as continue to extend your prayers, hopes, and best wishes to the family as it keeps them encouraged and hopeful. All donations to this campaign will go directly to offsetting the expenses the family is incurring during this time. Your support is needed urgently and anything you might offer is deeply appreciated.

title: Lifting Up Laura
text: As many of you may know, in August 2018 my 33-year old sister in law, Laura Allio and her husband Michael, received devastating news of a probable recurrence of her cancer. After nearly 18 months of chemo, radiation, a double mastectomy, more chemo and countless hospital visits, Laura was seemingly on the path to recovery from the stage 2b breast cancer diagnoses she received in April 2017, just 6 months after their sweet baby James was born. In January, Laura’s scans showed that there was no evidence of disease. Despite this, Laura was adamant that another scan be taken in mid-August to confirm that she was cancer free. While doctors noted an additional scan wasn’t needed, her persistence won and the scan was performed.As a shock to us all, on August 23, 2018 Laura and Michael received the devastating news that the scan showed a concerning spot on her liver. Laura’s doctors are confident that this lesion signifies a recurrence of her cancer and therefore, at the beginning of September, Laura will have the lesion removed and sent out for testing. This recurrence would put her at stage 4 cancer which means that more creative methods need to be put into place to ensure Laura has the strongest possibility to beat this. So many people have reached out to show their love and support, and to ask about ways they can help. This Go Fund Me Page is a way to help Laura and Michael access the care, resources, and lifestyle they need to give them all the strength to continue to fight like hell. Beyond cancer being devastating, it is expensive. Insurance will cover the scans, the surgeries, etc. but ALL other supplementary expenses are out of pocket. New costs pop up every day, but here is what we know they can expect soon. Those costs that are known for certain are listed below, however there are some costs we are not exactly sure of yet. Western Medicine- COBRA costs due to Laura carrying the insurance prior to the loss of her job earlier this year ($1600/month)- Flights to and from hospitals for second opinions, treatment, etc. (airline tickets will cost at least $300 each time they travel, not including hotel costs and other costs associated with being away from home)- Research on her lesion performed by Foundation One (a sample of her lesion will be sent out for testing to determine the type of cancer she is dealing with so she can best fight it)- Functional medicine expenses - A consult Dr. Nasha Winters who uses natural medicine to target stage 4 cancer successfully ($500 for just the consult, not including ongoing treatment) Eastern Medicine- Acupuncture 2x a week ($31 each session)- Natropath doctor visits twice a month ($200 each visit)- A treatment facility to focus on detoxification and finding the root cause of her cancer (approx. $10K, depending on the facility)- Research by Sator Therapeutics – Cost is TBD but likely in the thousands (this is a personalized approach to treatment in Europe that would allow Laura to receive a customized treatment based on her specific type of cancer)  - Additional exploratory medicine expenses that arise (This will be the driving cost of treatment going forward as Laura needs to determine the root cause of her cancer and be vigilant in her approach to treatment)- Mistletoe injections ($180 monthly)Lifestyle- Regular massage treatments ($40 each session)- Organic groceries weekly in lieu of a meal train or other meals dropped off ($200) – Laura is on a very strict diet and this will allow her to maintain it- Supplements ($180 a month)Despite the stage 4 diagnosis, Laura and Michael are confident that they can beat this. People live for many years and go into remission with this diagnosis, but this type of success requires a lot of work, exploration, alternative medicine, and the expenses that go along with it all. This Go Fund Me page will help to ensure that Laura and Michael can focus on her treatment and have relief from some of the expenses that will come their way in the future Following the removal of this mass in early September, we will know, for certain, if this is cancerous. Because the doctors believe it is, we would like to give Laura and Michael a jump start on the upcoming expenses. If, for some reason, the results of the test indicate that this mass is not cancerous, all funds will be refunded Thank you in advance for your generosity, love, and support.

title: Help the Burns Family Rebound!
text: As many of you have heard, the Burns family has suffered a major tragedy in their family.  On Friday June 16th Pete was in an accident that resulted in a Traumatic Brain Injury. Kristen, Pete and their five children have volunteered so much of their time and gifts to members of our community. It is hard to find someone that they have not helped or touched with their kindness in some way.  Many of you have asked how you can help. First of all, we would like to thank you for reaching out, allowing the family some privacy and offering prayers. Prayers are the one thing Kristen asked for and continues to ask for. However, because of the Burns overwhelming kindness to others many would like to do more.  This GoFundMe page has been created to do just that. It is where you can make a donation and offer up a prayer/wish for the family. Pete is making progress however it will be a long road ahead. This page will remain open during the family’s journey.  As the family feels comfortable they will periodically use this page to update you on Pete’s progress. In addition, you can continue to wish them well and donate as you can. On behalf of the family we thank you for truly showing what community is about and paying it forward.

title: Ismael Ortiz Rehabilitation Fund
text: Estimados colegas, amigos y familia. El pasado 3 de mayo nuestro compañero Ismael Ortiz Cartagena, Fellow de segundo año del programa de Cardiología en el Hospital de Veteranos sufrió de un derrame cerebral hemorrágico. Los que han tenido el placer de conocer a Ismael, sabemos que él se desvive por la medicina, él fue el ganador del primer lugar en nuestra competencia del Congreso anual de presentación de research de fellows. Él fue escogido para ser el Chief Fellow de su clase graduanda y fue aceptado para continuar su entrenamiento en el programa de Cardiología Intervencional de la Universidad de Florida en Jacksonville. Siempre se ha enfocado en dar la milla extra, dirigiendo y participando en múltiples estudios de investigación clínica buscando echar hacia adelante la Cardiología en Puerto Rico. Pero Ismael no solo se caracteriza por sus sobresalientes logros académicos. Con sus pacientes siempre demuestra empatía y humildad al momento de brindarles el mejor trato posible. Como colega y amigo siempre brinda lo mejor de sí para ayudar a su prójimo.Él siempre se ha hecho disponible para participar, ayudar, y educar en su programa de entrenamiento, en las actividades de la Sociedad Puertorriqueña de Cardiologia y las del American College of Cardiology de Puerto Rico.En estos momentos, él se encuentra hospitalizado y batallando por recuperar el movimiento de sus extremidades derechas/dominantes. No tenemos duda de que él tiene la fortaleza y el coraje para lograr una recuperación completa. Es de esperar que el camino va a ser difícil y va a requerir de mucha terapia para su pronta y completa recuperación. No queremos que nuestro colega se quede privado del mejor tratamiento posible por razones económicas. Ayúdennos a brillar luz en el camino de Ismael durante este momento de oscuridad para asegurarnos que él logre brillar por sí mismo como siempre lo ha hecho.Sus donaciones serán utilizadas directamente por Ismael y su familia para propósitos de pago de gastos médicos, equipos médicos, terapias, y gastos personales durante estos próximos meses que no podrá ejercer. Ismael nunca ha sido persona de pedir, ni de depender de otros para sus logros. Cuando se le hizo el acercamiento para ofrecerle esta ayuda, quiso dejar claro que todo dinero restante cuando logre su recuperación será donado a un ente benéfico. También expresó que tanto él, como su esposa y familia, se lo agradecen grandemente.Los donativos de esta campaña para el Dr. Ismael Ortíz serán entregados a su esposa la Dra. Yaneris Agosto y serán manejados directamente por ambos para para propósitos de pago de gastos médicos, equipos médicos, terapias, y gastos personales durante estos próximos meses que no podrá ejercer.

title: The MacDonald Family
text: Helping out the MacDonald family during this difficult time.Every little bit helps.A Note from Anabelle’s Mom:We are at Children’s again with Anabelle. She had a seizure at gymnastics Monday and we discovered yesterday that she has Idiopathic Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (IPAH). It is quite serious, as it is a disease. It is also rare, 1 in a million people have it. Thankfully, it is treatable with aggressive intervention. We also have time on our side since she is only 4 and still growing. There have also been great developments over the past five years in regards to treatment. We will be here for another two weeks they think. Soon we will be learning our options for medication and possibly making a tough decision. We were told her best option is through a permanent line surgically implanted, which breaks my heart, but once she is better she can lead a normal life. We are pulling the horizon much closer, taking it moment by moment, and learning about what our new normal will be like. Keep my family in your prayers.

title: Leah Lucky 13
text: We write this with such heavy hearts.  We lost our sweet, energetic and sassy Leah Murtha on June 19, 2018. Taken from us way too soon. Raymond and Jessica are heartbroken, along with the rest of our family. This tragic loss comes within 10 months of them losing their wife and mother Luci Lynch-Murtha, after her courageous battle with cancer.  We have had such an outpouring of love and support, it has been overwhelming and we want to say thank you. I know many people want to be able to do something so we set up this page so you can post your messages donate if you choose, but just a way for all of us to express our feelings and thoughts. Raymond and Jessica will receive all the proceeds from this page. Thank you so much again, for your support and love.

title: Jordan Wingate
text: On August 13, 2018, at 2:49AM, Officer Jordan Wingate (solo driver) was responding to a call of a suspicious persons in the area of 7th Street and Middle Harbor. The marked patrol vehicle traveling Eastbound in the 1900 block of Middle Harbor collided with a civilian car and then a parked semi-truck. Officer Wingate was extricated by the Oakland Fire Department and taken to a local hospital and is listed in critical condition. He is still in a comma, listed in critical but stable condition. The doctors advise that Officer Wingate’s fight to recovery has only just started. Officer Jordan Wingate is 23 years-old. Officer Wingate started his career with the Oakland Police Department as a Police Cadet in 2013. In 2016 he was hired as a Police Officer Trainee (POT) and graduated from the Oakland Police Department’s 176th Basic Academy on May 2017. Officer Wingate is currently assigned to the Patrol Division.

title: US Marine battling cancer
text: Sgt. Daniel Pedersen US Marine Corps (ret.)This is Dan Pedersen, a 24 year old Sergeant who just finished his 5 year tour of duty, with the US Marine Corps. He was stationed at Camp Pendleton, and served in the Middle East and in the South Pacific theater. He was officially discharged from the military on February 3rd, 2018. Shortly after returning home Dan developed a cough. He worked through the pain and discomfort but knew he needed further medical attention. Doctors found a tumor in his right lung on April 26th.  Dan then had his first surgery on April 29, 2018 and was diagnosed with a small cell Neuroendocrine Tumor. It is extremely rare to find this form of aggressive metastatic cancer in such a healthy young man. He has chosen a special form of immunotherapy, that is not covered by his insurance. This therapy includes two-three years of strict adherence to a personalized medical protocol. Through many miracles Dan is able to travel to receive these treatments. Currently, Dan is working as a certified EMS provider in downtown Salt Lake City for a ambulance agency. One of his many aspirations includes attending nursing school to further his education within the medical field. With proper treatment, Dan will still be able to accomplish these goals, have a family and live a normal, healthy life.Dan's friends and family have set up this GOFUNDME.COM account for the purpose of raising funds needed for this specialized immunotherapy treatment. Dan is highly motivated and positive. With your support, we know he can beat this cancer.Thank you all for your love and for your support in this very unexpected and challenging life development. If you would like to contact Dan, please send him a personal message. He will be posting his thoughts, feelings and all of his successes, everyday on this Facebook page.  https://www.facebook.com/sgtdanielpedersen?lst=100026069892175%3A100026069892175%3A1526354636 6670    Please feel free to post your comments or questions.            With warmest regards, Dan's family and friends.

title: FAITH, HOPE & LOVE FOR ADRIAN  V.
text: Hello Friends & Family,I am making this Gofundme for my cousin Adrian Valenzuela who is near and dear to my heart. Adrian is 21 years young and loves being around race horses and has a passion for  these beautiful animals. He grew up around them since the day he was born. Unfortunately on Saturday morning while working horses at Santa Anita Race Track he went down in a bad spill and was not able to get up. He was rushed to Huntington Memorial Hospital where they confirmed he had broken his back, broken ribs and he has no sense of feeling from the waist down. He will be going in for surgery within the next couple days on his spine in hopes for things to turn around. As we all know there will be medical bills and lots of therapy which is why we have created this to try to help out with him and the family. Any donation is very much appreciated. Please keep him in your thoughts and prayers and Always keep the Faith, Hope & Love strong for Adrian during this time. Thank you & God Bless!

title: Adaptive van for Nick
text: Please help Nicholas' family afford a van so he can be safely transported when they need to leave the home.Adaptive vans are needed to  safely transport medically complex and physically disabled people to and from doctor’s and therapy appointments. It also helps them have the ability to experience life outside of the home. Nicholas is a two year old deeply affected by cerebral palsy. He can't do things like sit up without assistance, lift his arms or push up to help those caring for him move him from place to place. He's a tall boy for his age and the risk of injury is high for both him and caregivers. Getting a van with the right equipment will help transfer him more safely than out of a car seat in a typical vehicle. Kids like Nick have bulky, heavy medical equipment, and if it's not used as intended, expensive repairs are needed. This happens when components that aren't intended to be broken apart need to be in order to fit into a car to go to multiple appointments, sometimes in the same day. Nick's family has some important visits to the Seattle Children's Hospital scheduled later in the summer with  specialists and they have to bring equipment that doesn't fit in their car.Nick's family will soon be selling their small SUV and hope to buy an adaptive van, but they need your help.RECENT VISIT TO DEALER TO SEE HOW NICK'S CHAIR FITSThis is Nick's story, told by his Mom and Dad:In June of 2016, my husband and I received a phone call that a little boy was born many states away to an unprepared mother and that the baby needed a family. We had been chosen for the task if we could quickly decide to take him. After a surprisingly short discussion and a long flight to meet him, it was obvious that Nick was meant to be our son. Because we had gotten him "overnight", our community rallied around us and started delivering clothing, strollers, a crib; almost everything we needed showed up miraculously at our doorstep in those early days.A few short months later, our perfect baby started to slip in meeting milestones and started exhibiting what medical professionals called "hypertonicity". He was unable to turn his head easily to the left and his leg and arm muscles were consistently tight. He also started having issues bottle feeding and he barely slept. The hardest part about the first few months was not knowing what was happening with him and feeling like we weren't giving him what he needed. Typical new parents, right? What we didn't know at that time is that Nick's brain had suffered a stroke early on in the pregnancy and he had a condition called bilateral schizencephaly  with polymicrogyria . When we received his diagnosis at 6 months of age, we were told that he probably wouldn't walk and that controlling his seizures and muscle tone would be life-saving as he grew.NICK'S FIRST EEG, WHERE HIS SEIZURE DISORDER WAS CONFIRMEDThe first year of his life was deeply disorienting for us and filled with hospital admissions, trips to the ER, trials and errors with feeding tubes, procedures, tests, sleepless nights and mastering a whole new vocabulary. We learned the difference between OT and PT, balanced appointments in the home and in-clinic and we signed him up for every service we could afford, leveraging the Early Intervention's Birth to 3 services. As his mother, I was unable to return to work and filled my time with going to support groups, hiring dependable caregivers and even attending seminars about neuroplasticity. Kids like Nick need help re-wiring the brain to use their muscles, including those supporting vision, so they can have hope for some sort of "normal" life.NICK AFTER HIS FIRST MEDICAL PROCEDURE TO GET A FEEDING TUBE, HELD BY DADAs symptoms of his brain disorder, Nick has cerebral palsy, intractable epilepsy, cortical vision impairment and other symptoms like trouble swallowing and digesting food. He doesn't use any words to communicate. He's followed by over 15 doctors and we see 6 therapists - Occupational Therapists, Physical Therapists, Vision Therapists - either weekly or monthly either in our home or in clinics.What my husband's health insurance doesn't cover has been paid out of pocket so far. Big expenses are looming because he's such a big boy and because he can't help us move him at all.  Expensive things like adding tracks in the ceiling to support his weight as we move him safely from one room to an adaptive bathroom - not yet built - or removing steps and replacing them with ramps to roll his chair. We need to find a space in home to accommodate durable medical equipment like his activity chair, an adaptive stroller or foam wedges to support him during vision therapy. He'll soon get a "stander" to help him bear weight so his hips can develop enough to avoid surgery.TWO OF THE PIECES OF LARGE EQUIPMENT WE NEED TO TRANSPORTThe tricky thing about medical equipment is that it's bulky and heavy. Not only do we need to protect our bodies as he grows but we need to protect the integrity of the equipment by not breaking it down when it needs to go with him to appointments. The retail cost of one of his pieces of equipment alone is over $7,000 and if it breaks, there are limited options for loaners. The process of getting the blue chair in the picture above through the local children's hospital, including insurance approvals, took almost 7 months!We've waited as long as possible to buy an adaptive van to safely transport Nick and his heavy medical equipment. Soon, he won't sit in a car seat and instead, his chair will be strapped down inside a van for transport. By purchasing a properly adapted one, we'll be able to roll Nick into it and reduce unnecessary wear and tear on the chairs. If you have ever shopped for a van, you know that they can be costly. If you add the conversion package, the cost is between $60,000 to $80,000 for a new one. The conversion offers essential features for families like ours, like:-    A wheelchair ramp that automatically retracts from the vehicle after the van is lowered closer to the ground. You might have seen this with buses being lowered to accommodate a passenger with physical limitations. -    Modular seating that can be easily removed to add space for large equipment or a disabled passenger in the front when they're old enough. Why should a person who would typically ride up front be pushed to the back of a van simply because they can't open a door and sit in the front seat?-    Illumination on the floors to see where you're working on tying down chairs or when you drop things like syringes while meds are administered.We've been setting aside money to buy the van but other expenses are adding up:  adapting our home, hiring additional caregivers so we can both work to afford therapies and treatments. So, we're asking for some help. We're lucky to have a fair, family-run and owned local dealership  in our area but we really need some help putting part of the money down to be able to afford the monthly payment.It's very hard to ask for help so publicly but we've been encouraged to do so by some of his doctors and therapists and we all need help from time to time.Thank you listening to our family's story and for your support. Even if you can't contribute financially, sharing our story with your friends and family or leaving a kind note is always appreciated. You can share the link by email, phone, Facebook or Twitter:   www.gofundme.com/VanforNick. Or, you can just use" share buttons" and mention why Nick's story inspired you to donate or share.Thank you again,Nick's Mom and Dad, Nick J.

title: Trotter Strong
text: Our old friend Tom Trott is battling ALS. He is confined to an electric wheelchair and can no longer speak, having to communicate via a text-to-voice device. The disease has progressed to the point where he needs in home care which isn't covered by insurance. The demands for in-home care will increase over time placing a financial strain on the family. If you are able, please donate to this site to help offset the tremendous cost of in-home care. To give you a sense of the Trott’s need, here are some estimates on caregiver costs they will soon face:    $5,000 (cost of four weeks of in-home caregiver services, 8 hours per day)    $1,250 (cost of one week, 8 hours per day)    $250 (cost of one 8-hour shift) To make a significant dent, we need some donations towards the upper end of the chart. However, we understand that each of you is in different financial circumstances. A donation of any size is appreciated and will add to the total amount we are able to raise for the Trott’s. Let's rally to help one of our brothers.Due to an overwhelming response, we increased the goal from the initial $25,000 target to a new $35,000 target. This extra money will allow the Trott’s to use additional caregiver services. They likely will need this and more. Thank you for your generous support!

title: We Love the Switskis
text: The Switzki family has reached a point where they could use your help.  Matt fought stage IV cancer for two and a half years.  He passed away peacefully in his home, where he was surrounded by the people dearest to him; Tricia, Kane, Elin, his parents, and Tricia's mom.  They had told Matt he had six months to live, and as strong as we all know he is, he beat those odds and never gave up his fight to the very end.Tricia is reluctantly accepting financial help.  She has never asked for help through it all.  So many people have asked what they can do to help, and this is one way we can all make her life a little more comfortable.  She was always Matt's rock and had been there with him every step of the way, 24/7.  There will be medical bills coming in that Tricia will have to find a way to pay.  She has been working full time, being a mom to Kane and Elin, and a care-taker for Matt for so long.  She hasn't looked at bills in months, because she wouldn't leave Matt's side when he was in the hospital.  He was her only focus, as it should have been.  Any amount you could donate to the family, would be wisely used as she see fits.If your son or daughter are on a team or activity with Kane or Elin this year, offer to drive or car pool to help Tricia out.  She has amazing family to be there for her, but sometimes something as simple as driving her kids, can be the biggest help.  Keeping Kane and Elin entertained, happy, and busy means more to Tricia than you could ever know.The most important thing in Matt's life was his family.  Please pray for them all.  There is nothing more important in life than love and family.

title: Diane Austin Medical Bills
text: Diane is a mother of two sons–Holden, 9 and Gavin, 7–who is now facing devastating life changes, loss of limbs after a simple surgery went wrong, and the inability to pay for most of the medical bills because insurance won’t cover them.On June 7, Diane went into what should have been a simple sinus surgery to help with chronic nasal infections she had been suffering from for months. The next day, she suffered from a 104-degree fever, a headache, nausea, rashes, vomiting, and diarrhea. She was taken to urgent care, where they eventually couldn’t find a blood pressure, and then she was rushed to the emergency room.Somehow, Diane had contracted an infection during the sinus surgery that had quickly become septic(bacterial infection in blood stream). She was taken into an emergency surgery, where her entire large colon and part of her small bowel were removed. She then spent almost two weeks in the ICU, unable to see her sons, and was taken back to surgery for an illeostomy and given a feeding tube (peg) as well. She wasn’t able to speak again until she was extubated on June 17th—her first words were, "Happy Father's Day."Because the infection became septic so drastically, Diane no longer has use of her fingers and feet, but she can currently stand briefly on her left foot. She struggles through having her wounds dosed with alcohol, wrapped, and unwrapped multiple times a day. She is also still suffering from a swollen small intestinal area with gas and stomach pains, a clogged feeding tube, anxiety, and minimal sleep. She is enduring physical therapy trying to regain mobility with hopes of returning home to her boys, husband, and the community that she knows and loves.The doctors are advising amputation. There is a possibility of hand transplants and a right below-the-knee amputation, as well as an partial amputation on her left foot. The doctors are also hopeful that more can be done to improve her small intestine, bar any more infections or setbacks. However, most of the above won’t be covered by her insurance or social security. The current estimate for what she’d have to pay out of pocket is over $500,000.The insurance will pay to put Diane in a nursing home, but refuses to pay for at-home health care, prosthetics, or the necessary procedures. The worst case would be Diane being placed in a nursing home at 35 years old, where she could only get visitation from her boys and husband after school and work, but would no longer be able to live with them. The family has yet to hear back from Medicaid, but we’re hoping that Diane will be accepted so that she and her sons can have some insurance if she were no longer to have insurance from her job due to her condition.We are asking for donations to this GoFundMe page to help pay off her medical bills that the insurance won’t cover, and for the ability to receive any prosthetics or at-home care she’s going to need moving forward.Thank you for reading, and thank you in advance for anything you can give.  Any little bit will help, even something as small as the price of a cup of coffee.  Please share to spread the word even if you can’t help monetarily!We thank God for His many blessings and that Diane is alive and can still hug her boys with her arms and talk to them. Through this whole ordeal her faith in God and multiple prayer group-support from Open Door Church, where she volunteers and where her boys to go to school and support has been a tremendous help. We thank everyone who has prayed and for the many churches across North Carolina, her family, and her friends that have gotten her this far.All funds raised will be withdrawn in a special bank account on behalf of Diane and the family.  Paula Loftin will work to oversee the withdrawals of the funds.

title: A CANCER FUNDRAISER FOR NASSO
text: There have been so many of you voicing concern about our long- time head bartender, NASSO, who has been MIA since the end of January. As of this new posting, we have collectively raised about $32,000 to support our longtime friend and favorite bartender in his most challenging year. I am happy to have spent a couple of days with Nasso this past week in the beginning of August, around and in my swimming pool, a scenario neither of us could have imagine even two weeks ago. It is a convenient place for him to begin a long process of rehab in tandem with his other physical therapy routines. He is in good spirits but still trying to process all the life changing events that have occurred these past 9 months.The good news about his bone marrow biopsy being negative was a big deal of course. He is still waiting on an additional report regarding the possible presence of an aberrant “t” cell that would make him more vulnerable in the future. Fingers crossed.In any case, Nasso will not be rejoining the work force anytime soon. The neuropathy in his legs, a direct result of the extensive chemotherapy, have disabled him. His once powerful arms and hands will need a lot of time and determination to recover. He has always been a physical guy and is ready and thankful to be able to get after it.Nasso is more than grateful for this Go Fund Me site. Our initial goal has been reached. But the future is still very uncertain for him. Up until now, Rancho Nicasio was able to cover his health insurance. He now has to rely on COBRA, which costs around $800 a month. Disability may help with his other living expenses for a while, but it’s just a situation nobody wants to be in.So I’m going to leave this site up for the immediate future and raise our goal.Your generosity has been exceptional. I’m reaching out to folks who may not have been aware or had the opportunity to contribute.

title: Play Ball for Desi
text: Our coach, teacher and friend Desi Herrera has recently been diagnosed with a glioblastoma brain tumor.  Fighting this horrible disease will require Desi and Freda to take time away from work as San Marcos Unified School District teachers. They must be able to focus on their three boys and the healing process without the pressure of the additional financial burden that accompanies this battle.Your support is needed and your contributions will help. Please consider donating to this amazing family.  No amount is too small and prayers are cherished.   With friends like you, and their amazing family, Desi and Freda have so much to fight for.  Thank you

title: KendallJoyCancerFight2018
text: I have started this page to raise money for my daughter Kendall's fight against Hodgkin's Lymphoma. She faced  this horrible disease 4 1/2 years ago and beat it, but on March 20th was given the heartbreaking news that it had returned. A lot has changed since Kendall's first battle with cancer. She got married, became a mother to my beautiful granddaughter, Sofia, and has continued her career. Kendall first noticed a lump under her arm about a month ago and immediately contacted her oncologist. He ordered a PET scan to check for any tumors she might have and also ordered a needle extraction biopsy. After the results of both tests were in, it was confirmed that the Hodgkin's Lymphoma was back.  She has a key lime sized tumor in her armpit, an orange sized tumor next to her heart and a small tumor under her collarbone. Kendall had a central line (port) surgically implanted in her chest on March 28th. This is how the chemo will be administered to her during treatment. Kendall will undergo 9 weeks of aggressive outpatient chemo in her hometown of Medford, Oregon starting next week. As soon as the chemo is complete she will undergo another PET scan to confirm that the chemo has killed the tumors. Next, Kendall will be moved to Portland, Oregon to get an even more aggressive chemo that will be given to her over 6 consecutive days. We were told she can expect the side effects from this treatment to be the harshest of anything she has faced to date, and will certainly cause her to lose her hair. Then the final and most brutal treatment will happen immediately after. The final treatment is a full bone marrow transplant that will remove all of Kendall's bone marrow, treat it with medication and her own stem cells and then return it to her body. This treatment will happen over a 4 week period and will put her white blood cell count at zero. Kendall's body will not have the ability to fight off even the weakest germs so this will be a very delicate time for her and our family. Kendall will be isolated from everyone except for her mother and I, who will care for her during the treatment and the 2 week recovery.  This will be a very rough time for her as she won't be able to have any contact with Sofia during this time.The funds we raise for her will be used to cover all of the outrageously expensive medical costs before, during and after her treatment that we already know her insurance won't cover. It will also be used for travel expenses to and from Portland, the 6 week housing for Kendall during the bone marrow transplant and recovery, and help with living expenses while Kendall is unable to work, which may be as long as 6 months. Kendall's husband Fily is working hard as a full time nursing student which makes it impossible for him to work at this time, so Kendall is the sole provider for her new family.For all of you that know me, this is the hardest thing I have ever had to do. I am a person that loves to give to others but at the same time find it so hard to ask for help, but this is an urgent situation. So from the bottom of my heart and on behalf of my entire family, I thank you for any support you can give.  Please share this link and continue to pray for my angel, Kendall Joy.

title: Help Kyle Kick Cancer
text: On April 13, our brother Kyle was diagnosed with stage IV glioblastoma, which is a type of brain cancer that is typically terminal. He had surgery on April 19 at Rush in Chicago to remove the main portion of the tumor. He is at home now, in Valparaiso, IN, recovering from surgery, but since the cancer is so aggressive, there is a long road ahead, which will include many chemo and radiation treatments that will begin over the next few weeks.All funds raised will be used solely for Kyle’s treatments, including the surgeries, doctors, chemo and radiation treatments and other medications.Everyone who has had the pleasure of knowing Kyle will tell you that he is hands down one of the kindest people they’ve ever met. Kyle is a smart, funny, quick-witted guy, who would do anything for those he loves. He has always had a strong love of nature and enjoys spending time hiking, skiing, rock climbing, playing frisbee golf, volley ball and many other sports. He also has an incredible passion for reading and connecting with others, whether playing lighthearted games or having profound conversations.Kyle is the kind of person who effortlessly forms deep bonds with those he meets, and he is adored by all who know him. Any monetary assistance you can provide (no amount is too small) to help ease this struggle for our brother would be greatly appreciated. Whether or not you are in a position to contribute financially, any and all prayers and positive thoughts are welcome.Thanks and love.

title: Team Codden
text: Dan and Colleen Codden are the parents of 2 beautiful girls Emma (10) and Ava (6) who live in Albany, NY.  Dan was recently diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL).  Although it's more common in children, Adult ALL is a cancer of the blood and bone marrow. This type of cancer can progress rapidly if it is not treated immediately.The course of treatment for ALL is aggressive and consuming.  Initial phases include inpatient chemotherapy, blood transfusions, radiation and antibiotics.  This disease is also prone to spread to the brain and spinal fluid, so weekly spinal taps are necessary to monitor conditions.  Finally, a bone marrow transplant may be recommended if the above treatment methods are not fully successful.  Dan and his family have a long road ahead of them.  It is expected that Dan will be out of work for a minimum of 6-8 months. As their family and friends, we want the absolute best care for Dan and we're reaching out for hope, prayers and for help. Through the generosity of our friends, family and strangers, any and all funds collected will be utilized to fund Dan’s care and the Codden’s living expenses over the next 6 months.  Any donation and prayer is a blessing and will very much be appreciated.  Please feel free to contact us through the campaign page for further information on how you can help.  Thank you.

title: Scott's Cancer Treatment
text: A letter from Scott and Anne:Hi everyone!I’ve started writing and started over several times, but I’m realizing that no words will be adequate to express our appreciation for what everyone has done for me and my family. When my oncologist told us that our best hope is flying to Switzerland for treatment, we decided to say yes without knowing how we would pull it off. It almost reminds me of the “trust fall,” where you fall backwards and believe that someone will be back there to catch you. In this case, our family, friends and a lot of people who we don’t even know not only caught us, but lifted us up more than we can believe. The amount of funds raised in a matter of hours and days was stunning. I never would have believed that we’d have this kind of response, especially after many of you have already given to us in the past. It seems like every day on every television channel and every internet story, we are told how divided we are in this country for a variety of reasons. To me - this has been the ultimate reminder that people really are good. A large community that is united by compassion and kindness has lifted us up when we needed it the most. A community, by the way, made up of people in many states, several countries, men and women, straight and gay, Republicans and Democrats, young and old, etc. It will be impossible for us to ever thank this community of kindness in a way that feels like enough. But from the bottom of my heart, I appreciate what each one of you has done for us. Whether it was a donation, sending us a dinner, saying a prayer, giving a hug on a tough day, or just being a friend, this community has meant everything to us - and I thank you. We will do our very best to pay your kindness forward in as many ways as we can in the future.So here we are - in Switzerland. I will be admitted into the hospital tomorrow morning, and will stay until Thursday. I want this treatment to be successful for the obvious reasons, but I also feel some strange pressure to make all of your support worth it. I know that’s a little crazy, but I don’t want to let everyone down. Once I’m injected with the isotope, I will literally be radioactive. Nobody (including Anne) will be able to be around me for a day and a half. People experience a wide range of side effects, so I’m not sure what to expect. I’m both excited about the treatment and also already nervous about the future results. We will keep you posted on how it goes. Thanks again and I love you all!-ScottUPDATE:**Thanks to your generosity, we were able to meet our initial goal in less than a day!! Since the interest in helping has been so high, we will continue and any additional funds will go towards Scott’s second and third treatments that will come to a total of $36,000.  We are overwhelmed by the response and I know that Scott and Anne are as well. **Our brother Scott continues his courageous battle with cancer.  With his wife Anne and son Alec by his side, he has fought every day.  His best option for treatment at this point takes them to Switzerland.  We are hoping to raise enough to help him pay for his first treatment and anything additional will go toward subsequent treatments (he has to go 3 times).   We want them to be able to focus on getting the best treatment he can and enjoying every day without worrying about medical and traveling costs.  When we approached Scott about additional fundraising, he finally agreed but only if we would add a personal letter to you all.  We have attached the letter below.  Thank you from the bottom of our hearts.  As a family, we appreciate all your support.Renee & MichelleHi Friends and Family,First, we want to thank all of you who have offered to set up a fundraising site for us. We have agreed to let my sisters create one, but felt like we needed to tell everyone why. Since my diagnosis, we have gotten so much support.  People have set up fundraisers for us over the last few years.  There were times when we thought we had been given way too much and would eventually need to donate it to a non-profit.   However, this journey turned out to be more challenging (and more expensive) than we realized.    Our eyes are now wide-open to healthcare in America, and people with rare diseases are really in a tough spot. Luckily, we have you.  Trust me, without you all I might not be here today.  And if I were, we certainly would not still be living in our house or be able to send Alec to daycare.   We cannot thank everyone enough for all of the prayers and support.  We absolutely could not do it without you.   Up until now I have been able to see the best specialists in the country at MD Anderson in Texas and James Cancer Center in Ohio.  I have tried several clinical trials, but the cancer has continued to act very aggressively.   All of the specialists agree that my best chance now is a full body radiation procedure called PRRT.   It is an amazing treatment that can target all of the bone tumors in my body (I have many, many of them now).  It has been approved by the FDA for the more common types of neuroendocrine cancers, but not for mine.  Since insurance does not cover anything not approved by the FDA – we’re out of luck.  Believe it or not, it is less expensive to go to another country and pay out of pocket for the procedure than it is to get it here at the hospital in Pittsburgh without help from insurance.   We have made the decision to go to Basel, Switzerland to get the first round of PRRT.  The first treatment alone will be $12,000 (there are 3 treatments overall, 10 weeks apart), and there will obviously be significant travel expenses.  The cost is high, and it was not an easy decision for me, but I feel like no matter what happens, Alec has to know that I did everything that I possibly could to spend more time with him.  And besides, I haven’t given up yet. And I don’t plan on it.   We want you to know that you have already done your part.   Nobody should feel like they need to contribute again.  We love you all so much for everything that you have already done and nothing will change that.   We agreed to this because many are asking what else they can do, and honestly – we need some help.  Not counting the trip(s) overseas, the costs of endless appointments, prescriptions and travel add up quickly.  It has been very humbling to go from a life where we never had to worry about finances, to a place where we have to admit that we can’t do it on our own.  We can only say that your thoughts, prayers, kindness and support have meant everything to us and we’ll do everything that we can to pay it forward when we are able. Love,Scott, Anne & Alec

title: Smith Strong
text: Meet the Smith Family. Jodi and Casey have been married for 17 years. The have 6 amazing kids. Hallie-15 Olivia-14 Luke-11 Lincoln-10 Emma-6 and Bo-3. This is no ordinary family. You can find the Smith’s constantly serving others, always having fun but most of all, they are always together. You will not find better kids or more devoted parents. In the fall of 2017, Jodi was diagnosed with stage 4 Ovarian Cancer. After months of difficult chemotherapy treatments and one major surgery, Jodi received a clean bill of health. A true miracle.About a week after her clean scans, Jodi packed up the kids and headed to Utah for a family-filled summer with the kiddos. Casey stayed home to work with plans to meet up with the family at a later date. A few days into the trip, Jodi received a phone call that Casey had collapsed and had two seizures while helping a friend move. Jodi caught a plane in the middle of the night to be by Casey’s side. Casey was diagnosed with Glioblastoma multiforme. An inoperable tumor in the brain. Casey will receive radiation and chemotherapy as treatment as this tumor does not yet have a cure.To know the Smith family is to love them. The Smith kids are incredible examples, faithful as can be and righteous in all they do. Plus, they are fun-loving, hilarious and love each other deeply. To say they’ve had more than their fair share is an understatement but they persevere and continue to choose the right. It is absolutely amazing how these kids have handled the cards that have been dealt to them with both of their parents being diagnosed with cancer. It’s a true testament of good values and a strong family unit.We’ve set up this account to hopefully provide some relief to their family at this time but also because so many people have asked to help. We are truly grateful for all the people who have rallied together and lifted this incredible family up by serving, sending texts, calling, helping with the kids, providing meals, serving others but most of all praying. We’ll continue to pray, pray, pray as we support the Smith’s and Casey.  #smithstrong

title: Chris Gough Support Fund
text: On Feb. 19, 2018, Chris went to the ER with severe stomach pain. 3 days before that, he had visited a doctor for a very benign procedure, however later that evening didn’t feel well. He chalked it up to the flu, since it was rampant around town. From the moment he arrived at the ER, his life took a turn that none of us could have ever imagined. Chris didn’t have the flu. Chris was septic. The procedure he had caused a Strep A infection in his blood that traveled throughout his entire body and all of the sudden he was fighting for his life. Chris experienced multiple organ failure, was intubated (on a ventilator), on dialysis and a team of doctors did all they could to save his life. The next few weeks in the Intensive Care Unit proved to be devastating. Chris went thru endless tests with rounds of doctors trying to stabilize his condition. After being intubated for over 2 weeks, doctors chose to perform a tracheotomy so that he could breathe without a tube in his voice box and to reduce the likelihood of infection.Chris had been through the ringer. His body had just barely survived multiple organ and acute heart failure. Then, he couldn’t move his arms or legs. Like many ICU patients who are that close to death, Chris was diagnosed with Critical Illness Neuropathy/Myopathy. This news was beyond anything we were expecting. The Neurologist said that in the 30 years he has been practicing he has never seen such a severe case. He said it may be months or years before Chris will be able to move again, from his neck down. He is not able to breathe on his own, nor able to speak. He is fed through a feeding tube to his stomach.The doctors announced on March 20th that the best course at this time to take would be to transfer Chris to a Long Term Care Facility and out of ICU, where he has now been for the past month. Chris may require professional care for a long time, perhaps the rest of his life.Chris and his wife own a wonderful CPA practice that they acquired after his wife’s step father passed away almost 2 years ago and they were gifted his business. This is their ONLY source of income. They have 2 little girls, ages, 1 ½ and 3 1/2. The financial burden on this family is overwhelming and they will not be able to take on all of the financial responsibilities alone.Our hope and prayer is for Chris to recover and one day regain mobility for independent living. Chris is well known by friends & family for his smile, charm and dedication to wife and children. His family gives heartfelt thanks for the love and kindness they have received to date. Please help support Chris in his time of need! This will help his family with medical expenses and rehabilitation.With love,His Family

title: Support Kikkan's Fight!
text: Dear fellow friends of Kikkan,By now you’ve heard the news that Kikkan was diagnosed with breast cancer and is in Anchorage undergoing treatment.  Although Kikkan has insurance, not all of her associated medical costs are covered, requiring Kikkan and Jeff to face fairly significant out of pocket costs.   We’re looking to raise $45,000 to help offset the personal impact to Kikkan and her family and any funds that exceed their associated expenses will be donated to AKTIV against cancer. Your donation will go a long way in supporting her fight during a very difficult time. Thank you so much for your consideration.Friends of Kikkan

title: Help the Howlett's
text: Please help support our dear friend Amy Mcbride-Howlett and her family of six (four children ages 4-13) by donating your money and prayers.  In 2013, at the age of 34, Amy was diagnosed with stage 3 glioblastoma, an aggressive form of brain cancer.  The family recently learned the news that it has returned and is terminal.  The doctors have given Amy very little time left and so we are reaching out to friends to raise money and support, to help ease the financial burden on her family.  It has been a very emotional 5 years for the Howlett family.  Prior to her diagnosis in 2013, Amy spent 10 weeks in the hospital hoping for a miracle for her babies, after experiencing premature labor.  Calvin and Harper were born, 12 weeks premature and spent 10 weeks in the NICU, until they were strong enough to breathe and eat on their own.  Finally, after 20 weeks of hospitalizations, the family of six, including her two older boys Noah and Carson, were re-united at their home. About a month later, Amy began to experience numbness/paralysis on her left side and face.  Amy went through a whirlwind of misdiagnoses and treatments, including MS treatments that led to a severe allergic reaction. Sadly, after biopsy confirmation, she was diagnosed with brain cancer.  In 2013-2014 Amy underwent months of chemotherapy, radiation and then eventually surgery to remove her original brain tumor and miraculously has been cancer free for the past 4 years.  Amy remained paralyzed on her left side from the original tumor but was otherwise able to lead a normal, happy life and mother her children as they have grown.  Sadly, about 9 months ago she started experiencing dizziness and a decline in speech and mobility that has continued to worsen and included a hospital stay in December for pneumonia.  Amy has been unable to speak and walk since August and the burden of care for herself and her four children has been on her family and, in particular, her amazing husband Sean.  We hope to raise funds to help pay for services, medical costs and other unexpected costs. Thank you for your prayers and support.

title: Blake's Cancer Fight
text: Those of us who are fortunate to know Blake Loebs know that he is a dedicated husband,  loving father, hardworking lawyer and a friend to anyone he meets. With his wife Alisa by his side, Blake enjoys watching and playing sports with his 7-year old son, Ryan. Ryan, a sensitive soul, shares his love of the Warriors and SF Giants with Blake and is 100% a daddy's boy. Blake's 5-year old daughter, Amanda, is the extrovert of the family. She an artist at heart and loves to perform her favorite dance moves for her family.In his professional life, Blake is a Principal with Meyers Nave.  He joined the firm in 2015 after serving 22 years as a Deputy City Attorney for the City and County of San Francisco.  Blake leads the firm’s statewide Peace Officer Defense/Civil Rights Practice. In 2013, the San Francisco Police Officers Association honored Blake as the “Citizen of the Year” and awarded him the Medal of Honor, the two highest honors that can be bestowed on civilians, reflecting his special expertise defending officer-involved shooting cases.Blake was recently diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. He is committed to fighting cancer with the same tenacity that he brings to fighting for his clients. He has a big fight ahead of him and needs to focus on this fight and not worry about financial matters. Sometimes people aren't sure how to help in times like this, but here is the answer: contribute any amount, no matter how small to help Blake and his family. We want Blake and Alisa to be free of financial worry so they can focus on his treatment and enjoying time together as a family. Together we can make a difference in helping out a dear friend who means so much to all of us. Thank you so much for your generosity!

title: Join Amy Tortorella's Fight
text: It started with slight back pain and she didn't  think too much of it.   But as the pain substantially increased over the next couple weeks, Amy went to see a back specialist as she had a fast approaching trip to Morocco as the leader of a yoga retreat.  Just 2 days later she was admitted to Duke University Hospital with a diagnosis of Stage 4 pancreatic cancer. Described by her yoga family as "a strong presence embodying light, love and awakening.  Amy is a goddess whose light embraces all who are fortunate to cross her path. "  Her yoga classes in Raleigh create a safe space to practice many principles of yoga extending far beyond the physical asana.  Amy is married to my brother, her college sweetheart, Ian.  They met in 1996 at Myrtle Beach, SC while Ian was finishing his degree at Coastal Carolina University and Amy was enrolled in ECU.  Instead of migrating back north to Boston after graduation, Ian moved to Greenville, NC to be closer to Amy.  They settled in Raleigh, NC and share a love for friends, family, yoga, hockey, beer and of course their fur babies.  Amy and Ian's family, friends,  hockey and yoga family's outreach and support has been overwhelming and they are so appreciative.  All of the support is giving them the strength they need to fight this together.  Amy is fortunate to have some of the best cancer facilities in the country in their backyard.  She is starting aggressive chemotherapy at UNC/REX this week.  Together, Amy and Ian continue to fight and explore treatment options. Unfortunately, the cost of treatment is exorbitant and financially challenging especially on one income.  So many have expressed a desire to support Amy and Ian so I wanted to set up this page and hopefully alleviate some of the financial burdens of the mounting medical bills.

title: Flavia Davis Cancer Fight Fund
text: There are way too many amazing people who are battling cancer or who lost their battle with this horrible disease.  When cancer hits close to home affecting those you love and admire the passion to speak up for those affected most becomes too strong to settle for, “There’s nothing they can do.” Something, even if it’s one thing can always be done. Flavia Davis, a valued and loved nurse, wife and most importantly mother, has cared for so many adults and children over her extensive career.  Her exemplary work ethics and compassionate care made her instrumental in the initiation of nursing programs in Radiology and at Pediatric MRI and PACU.Then in 2016, Flavia was diagnosed with ovarian cancer.  This devastating news wrenched the hearts of all that know her, but Flavia remained resilient. She underwent several surgeries, radiation and chemotherapy, and suffered some severe complications where most would throw their hands up, but not Flavia.  She got on her road to recovery supported by her husband and young son. She was able to return to work doing what she loves and caring for those in need. After a routine checkup later that year, a small spot was discovered in her left lung and thus began another round of chemo.  Three months of treatment and things were looking hopeful. Even when the chemo was leaving her exhausted she pushed through caring for those at work and home. Then devastating news came end of June this year when she went in for her 3 month checkup. The tumor doubled in size and 5 additional tumors were found in her left lung. The cancer doctor said there is nothing they can do because it is so close to the mediastinum.  Flavia's battle with this very aggressive and rare form of cancer now has  her at risk of losing her medical benefits due to missing work to get the treatment she needs.  We think something can be done.  A prayer, a hope, your support in donating to help this beautiful soul so she can enjoy her husband and son as long as her destiny allows.  Every minute is more precious now, and it’s so sad that it takes news such as this to open your eyes to the wonder of life and the value of time.  So do something.  Let's not stop at words, She wouldn't!!!
